instruction: What is the purpose of MIL-STD-6016?
input: SCOPE 1.1 PURPOSE The purpose of MIL-STD-6016 is to describe the approved standards to achieve compatibility and interoperability between command and control and communications systems and equipment of U.S. military forces employed or intended to be employed in joint tactical operations.
output: The purpose of MIL-STD-6016 is to describe the approved standards to achieve compatibility and interoperability between command and control and communications systems and equipment of U.S. military forces employed or intended to be employed in joint tactical operations.

instruction: What is the purpose of this publication?
input: This publication is to be complemented by CJCSM 6120.01, Joint Multi-Tactical Data Link (TDL) Operating Procedures (JMTOP), which will provide for planning and common procedures to be used by forces in the joint tactical environment using Link 16 as the basis for information exchange.
output: To complement CJCSM 6120.01, Joint Multi-Tactical Data Link (TDL) Operating Procedures (JMTOP), which will provide for planning and common procedures to be used by forces in the joint tactical environment using Link 16 as the basis for information exchange.

instruction: What does Section 4 of Link 16 contain?
input: Section 4 contains the general requirements, conventions, and protocols for information exchange and forwarding on Link 16. Section 5 contains the detailed requirements for the Link 16 fixed format message construction and the J-Series word descriptions. Shown for each Link 16 message is the message designator, purpose, format, transmit/receive rules, word map, word description and field coding.
output: Section 4 contains the general requirements, conventions, and protocols for information exchange and forwarding on Link 16.

instruction: What does the J-Series word descriptions contain?
input: The specific J-Series word descriptions are contained in three parts separated from the main volume of MIL-STD 6016; Part 1 contains the detailed descriptions for Link 16 words J0 through J6; Part 2 contains the detailed descriptions for Link 16 words J7 through J12; Part 3 contains the detailed descriptions for Link 16 words J12 through the RTT words.
output: The J-Series word descriptions contain detailed descriptions for Link 16 words and RTT words.

instruction: What does the text say about Section 6?

output: Section 6 contains notes of a general nature that apply to the use of this document.

instruction: What does the text say about the Link 16 Interface?
input: Appendix A identifies the minimum implementation requirements that must be met by all Service/Agency (S/A) systems participating on the Link 16 Interface. Satisfaction of these joint data exchange requirements is mandatory to establish and maintain the Link 16 Interface, to participate within a specific technical function, and to prevent adverse effects on the interface.
output: The Link 16 Interface requires all participating Service/Agency (S/A) systems to meet minimum implementation requirements for joint data exchange. This is mandatory to establish and maintain the interface, participate in specific technical functions, and prevent adverse effects.

instruction: What are the minimum implementation requirements that must be satisfied?
input: Minimum implementation requirements must be satisfied at each of seven different levels: functional, related function, message, related message, word, data element, and data item.
output: The minimum implementation requirements must be satisfied at seven different levels: functional, related function, message, related message, word, data element, and data item.

instruction: What are the requirements defined in the text?
input: These requirements are defined in terms of transmission and reception for both Command and Control JTIDS Units (C[2] JUs) and nonC[2] JUs.
output: The requirements are defined in terms of transmission and reception for both Command and Control JTIDS Units (C[2] JUs) and nonC[2] JUs.

instruction: What does DFI stand for?

The DFI includes a single concept and is the generic representation of the DUIs grouped under it. The DUIs, which are representative of the DFI concept, contain the Data ``` ----- ``` Items (DIs) used to compose the data element. instruction: What does Appendix C contain?
input: Appendix C contains the data forwarding rules, protocols, and translations required between J series and M series messages.
output: Appendix C contains the data forwarding rules, protocols, and translations required between J series and M series messages.

instruction: What is data forwarding?
input: Data forwarding is the process of receiving data on one digital data link and outputting the data in the proper format and protocol of another digital data link.
output: The process of receiving data on one digital data link and outputting the data in the proper format and protocol of another digital data link.

instruction: What is the process of translating messages on one link to another link?
input: In the process, a message(s) received on one link is translated to an appropriate message(s) on another link.
output: In the process, a message(s) received on one link is translated to an appropriate message(s) on another link.

instruction: What does the text say about the role of systems that forward data?
input: All systems that forward data must adhere to Appendix C. In the course of implementing Link 16, it is recognized that some systems may use internal system translations (e.g., Link 16 to Link 11B) and some systems may transmit originated track data on more than one data link at the same time. Functionally, such systems are not data forwarders; however, they will adhere to the guidance in Appendix C to ensure that the closest possible relationship of data elements and data element interpretation will be maintained among all users of the data.
output: Systems that forward data must adhere to Appendix C. They will ensure that the closest possible relationship of data elements and data element interpretation will be maintained among all users of the data.

output: Appendix D describes the Link 16 implementation by each service/agency participating in the Link 16 joint interface.

output: The text shows the implementation from the functional level down to the data item level for each system.

instruction: What was established by JCS Memorandum SM-205-71?
input: ``` ----- ``` 1.3 BACKGROUND JCS Memorandum SM-205-71, 1 April 1971, established a program to ensure the joint interoperability of tactical command and control systems in support of the Ground and Amphibious Military Operations (GAMO) Program. The Joint Interoperability of Tactical Command and Control Systems (JINTACCS) Program was established by JCS Memorandum SM-184-78, 7 March 1978, to replace the GAMO Program, although directives that were pertinent to the GAMO Program are considered applicable to the JINTACCS Program.
output: JCS Memorandum SM-205-71 established a program to ensure the joint interoperability of tactical command and control systems in support of the Ground and Amphibious Military Operations (GAMO) Program.

instruction: What was established by JCS Memorandum SM-184-78?
input: ``` ----- ``` 1.3 BACKGROUND JCS Memorandum SM-205-71, 1 April 1971, established a program to ensure the joint interoperability of tactical command and control systems in support of the Ground and Amphibious Military Operations (GAMO) Program. output: JCS Memorandum SM-184-78 established the Joint Interoperability of Tactical Command and Control Systems (JINTACCS) Program to replace the GAMO Program.

instruction: What is the purpose of the JTIDS/MIDS program?
input: The JTIDS/MIDS program was established as a Joint Service Program to develop and acquire a secure, jamresistant communications system with inherent capabilities to support information distribution, relative navigation, and identification that would support both intra- and inter-Service information exchange between tactical command and control facilities/systems.
output: To develop and acquire a secure, jam-resistant communications system with inherent capabilities to support information distribution, relative navigation, and identification that would support both intra- and inter-Service information exchange between tactical command and control facilities/systems.

instruction: What is the purpose of JCS Memorandum SM-362-75?
input: JCS Memorandum SM-362-75, 2 July 1975, stipulates the relationship between the JTIDS/MIDS and GAMO (now the JINTACCS) Programs.
output: JCS Memorandum SM-362-75 stipulates the relationship between the JTIDS/MIDS and GAMO (now the JINTACCS) Programs.

instruction: What does JTIDS/MIDS provide?
input: JTIDS/MIDS may provide either primary or alternate transmission means through which appropriate tactical data systems are interconnected.
output: JTIDS/MIDS provides either primary or alternate transmission means through which appropriate tactical data systems are interconnected.

instruction: What was the purpose of the GAMO Executive Agent?
input: The Joint Chiefs of Staff had directed the GAMO Executive Agent (EA) (SM-575-77, 27 June 1977) to develop the message standard for the JTIDS/MIDS, which included the development of a JTIDS Technical Interface Concept (JTIC) and a JTIDS Technical Interface Design Plan - Test Edition (JTIDP-TE), as well as the responsibility to plan, schedule, conduct, and evaluate joint testing of the JTIDP in order to validate its compatibility and interoperability for the Joint Chiefs of Staff.
output: To develop the message standard for the JTIDS/MIDS, including the development of a JTIDS Technical Interface Concept (JTIC) and a JTIDS Technical Interface Design Plan - Test Edition (JTIDP-TE), as well as planning, scheduling, conducting, and evaluating joint testing of the JTIDP to validate its compatibility and interoperability for the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

instruction: What is the purpose of the JINTACCS Program?

output: The text does not provide information on the purpose of the JINTACCS Program.

instruction: What was established by DOD Directive 5154.28?
input: On 5 July 1984, the Deputy Secretary of Defense signed DOD Directive 5154.28, which established the Joint Tactical Command, Control and Communications ``` ----- ``` Agency (JTC3A) under the Defense Communication Agency (DCA), and assigned to it responsibility for the development and maintenance of a joint architecture, interface standards, and interface definitions for tactical/mobile C[3] systems.

instruction: What is concurrent operations?

instruction: What is the local database of a concurrent operating unit?

instruction: What is the purpose of Geodetic Position Quality (Qpg)?

instruction: What is Geodetic Position Quality reported as?

instruction: What does the term 'Handover' refer to in the context of aircraft control?

instruction: What is a handover action?

instruction: What is the purpose of the leading bits in a message?

instruction: What is Interface?

instruction: What is JTIDS?
input: (Joint Pub 1-02) ``` ----- ``` JTIDS Joint Tactical Information Distribution System. The JTIDS/ MIDS is a joint-service system which provides an Integrated Communications, Navigation, and Identification (ICNI) capability. The JTIDS/MIDS provides a reliable, secure, jam resistant, high capacity, ICNI capability through the use of direct-sequence, spread spectrum, frequency-hopping, and error detection and correction techniques.
output: JTIDS stands for Joint Tactical Information Distribution System. It is a joint-service system that provides an Integrated Communications, Navigation, and Identification (ICNI) capability.

instruction: What are the features of JTIDS/MIDS?

output: It is one of 128 time-division structures comprising a JTIDS/MIDS network.

instruction: What does each net consist of?
input: Each net consists of a continuous stream of time intervals (time slots) with 98,304 time slots per 12.8-minute epoch, during which digital data whose signal characteristics are determined by a cryptographic variable in conjunction with a unique net number are distributed.
output: Each net consists of a continuous stream of time intervals (time slots) with 98,304 time slots per 12.8-minute epoch.

instruction: What is the total usable capacity of JTIDS/MIDS Network per epoch per net?
input: JTIDS/MIDS Network The JTIDS/MIDS structure (usable only with Mode 1 communications) having a total usable capacity of 98,304 time slots per epoch per net and 128 nets.

instruction: What is the structure of JTIDS/MIDS Network?

instruction: How many nets are there in JTIDS/MIDS Network?
input: JTIDS/MIDS Network The JTIDS/MIDS structure (usable only with Mode 1 communications) having a total usable capacity of 98,304 time slots per epoch per net and 128 nets.

instruction: What is the synchronization of nets?
input: All nets are synchronized so that each time slot of each net is time-coincident with the corresponding time slot (same set and number) of every other net.
output: All nets are synchronized so that each time slot of each net is time-coincident with the corresponding time slot (same set and number) of every other net.

instruction: What determines the signal characteristics of all data distributed within a specified multinetted structure?

instruction: What does a JTIDS/MIDS transmission consist of?
input: ``` ----- ``` Mode 1 Communications Mode 1 JTIDS/MIDS transmissions consist of a sequence of wide-band transmission symbol packets (single pulse, 13-microsecond packets and double-pulse, 26-microsecond packets), the pulses of which are formed by continuous phase shift modulation (CPSM) of the carrier frequency. The signal processing required to transform base-band data to the JTIDS signal waveforms for transmission includes base-band data encryption, forward error correction encoding, error detection encoding, cyclic code shift keying (CCSK) encoding, data symbol interleaving, and the selection of a variable start time.

output: The purpose of pooling time slot blocks in JTIDS/MIDS Class 2 Terminal is to satisfy a particular functional requirement or to divide the total JTIDS/MIDS capacity into pools to meet all functional requirements.

instruction: What is Position Reference One or more JUs designated as a network reference?
input: Position Reference One or more JUs designated as a network reference.

instruction: What is the geodetic position accuracy of the JU?
input: Such a JU has maintained a geodetic position accuracy of 50 feet, one sigma (standard deviation) over a long period of time.
output: 50 feet, one sigma (standard deviation) over a long period of time.

instruction: What is Primary User A subscriber terminal?
input: Primary User A subscriber terminal that utilizes the active synchronization (RTT) procedure and serves as a high quality source for synchronization by the general Relative Navigation community.

instruction: What is a Pulse (JTIDS/MIDS)?
input: (System Segment Specification for JTIDS/MIDS Class 2 Terminal) Pulse (JTIDS/MIDS) A 6.4-microsecond burst of carrier frequency continuous phase shift modulated at a 5-megabit-per-second rate by the transmission symbol.

instruction: What is the purpose of the System Segment Specification for JTIDS/MIDS Class 2 Terminal?

instruction: What is the function of time delay relaying?
input: ``` ----- ``` Radio Relaying A function for extending radio coverage based on time delay relaying where a message received during one time slot is subsequently retransmitted in another time slot.
output: It extends radio coverage by retransmitting a message received during one time slot in another time slot.

instruction: What is Radio Silence Mode?
input: (System Segment Specification for JTIDS/MIDS Class 2 Terminal) Radio Silence Mode A mode of terminal operation where the terminal receives but does not transmit fixed word format or variable message format messages. instruction: What is the acknowledgment of a message and/or an indication of intent to respond to a message called?

instruction: What is Recurrence Rate?
input: Recurrence Rate The total number of time slots per epoch assigned (or deleted) in a single time block assignment, specified as an integer, R = 0 to 15 where 2 = the number of time slots.
output: The total number of time slots per epoch assigned (or deleted) in a single time block assignment, specified as an integer, R = 0 to 15 where 2 = the number of time slots.

instruction: What is the purpose of RNN in System Segment Specification for JTIDS/MIDS Class 2 Terminal?

output: RNN is used to determine the recurrence rate of the block assignment.

instruction: What is Reed-Solomon Code applied to JTIDS/MIDS?
input: Reed-Solomon Code As applied to JTIDS/MIDS, a forward error correction encoding scheme using a 32-ary cyclic block code in the class of generalized Bose Chaudhuri-Hocquenguem (BCH) codes where the basic block codeword is a (31, 15)codeword, i.e., 31 5-bit data symbols per codeword, of which 15 are information symbols and 16 are parity symbols.
output: a forward error correction encoding scheme using a 32-ary cyclic block code in the class of generalized Bose Chaudhuri-Hocquenguem (BCH) codes

instruction: What are the basic block codewords in Reed-Solomon Code applied to JTIDS/MIDS?
input: Reed-Solomon Code As applied to JTIDS/MIDS, a forward error correction encoding scheme using a 32-ary cyclic block code in the class of generalized Bose Chaudhuri-Hocquenguem (BCH) codes where the basic block codeword is a (31, 15)codeword, i.e., 31 5-bit data symbols per codeword, of which 15 are information symbols and 16 are parity symbols.
output: The basic block codeword is a (31, 15) codeword, i.e., 31 5-bit data symbols per codeword, of which 15 are information symbols and 16 are parity symbols

instruction: What are message headers?
input: Message headers are (16,7) codewords which are shortened (31,15) codewords where 7 are information symbols and 9 are parity symbols.
output: They are (16,7) codewords which are shortened (31,15) codewords where 7 are information symbols and 9 are parity symbols.

instruction: What is Relative Azimuth Quality (Qar)?
input: (System Segment Specification for JTIDS/ MIDS Class 2 Terminal) ``` ----- ``` Relative Azimuth Quality (Qar) A measure of the quality of a terminal's estimate of the orientation of the U,V grid with respect to grid North.
output: A measure of the quality of a terminal's estimate of the orientation of the U,V grid with respect to grid North.

instruction: What is Relative Azimuth Quality?
input: Relative Azimuth Quality is reported in the terminal's Position and Status Reports as an integer from 0-7, where the higher numbers correspond to the higher qualities, i.e., lower errors in angular orientation.
output: It is reported in the terminal's Position and Status Reports as an integer from 0-7, where higher numbers correspond to higher qualities, i.e., lower errors in angular orientation.

instruction: What is the purpose of Relative Common Grid?
input: (System Segment Specification for JTIDS/MIDS Class 2 Terminal) Relative Common Grid A rectilinear planar grid tangent to the Earth surface at the grid origin whose coordinates are U, V Cartesian coordinates, where the V axis is the North-South axis and the U-axis is the East-West axis. (System Segment Specification for JTIDS/MIDS Class 2 Terminal) Relative Navigation A procedure used by a terminal to determine its position and velocity in a common reference coordinate system by passive observations of Position and Status messages transmitted by other terminals. (System Segment Specification for JTIDS/MIDS Class 2 Terminal) Relative Position Quality (Qpr) A measure of the quality of a terminal's relative position with respect to the U, V relative grid. Relative Position Quality is reported in the terminal's Position and Status Reports as an integer from 0-15, where the higher qualities, i.e., less error in position.
output: The Relative Common Grid is used to define a rectilinear planar grid tangent to the Earth surface at the grid origin, with U and V Cartesian coordinates where the V axis represents the North-South axis and the U-axis represents the East-West axis.

(System Segment Specification for JTIDS/MIDS Class 2 Terminal) Relative Position Quality (Qpr) A measure of the quality of a terminal's relative position with respect to the U, V relative grid. Relative Position Quality is reported in the terminal's Position and Status Reports as an integer from 0-15, where the higher qualities, i.e., less error in position.
output: Relative Navigation is a procedure used by a terminal to determine its position and velocity in a common reference coordinate system by observing Position and Status messages transmitted by other terminals.

instruction: What does Relative Position Quality (Qpr) measure?
input: (System Segment Specification for JTIDS/MIDS Class 2 Terminal) Relative Common Grid A rectilinear planar grid tangent to the Earth surface at the grid origin whose coordinates are U, V Cartesian coordinates, where the V axis is the North-South axis and the U-axis is the East-West axis. (System Segment Specification for JTIDS/MIDS Class 2 Terminal) Relative Position Quality (Qpr) A measure of the quality of a terminal's relative position with respect to the U, V relative grid. Relative Position Quality is reported in the terminal's Position and Status Reports as an integer from 0-15, where the higher qualities, i.e., less error in position.
output: Relative Position Quality measures the quality of a terminal's relative position with respect to the U, V relative grid. It is reported as an integer from 0-15, with higher values indicating less error in position.

instruction: What is a Remote Track?

instruction: What is Round-Trip-Timing (RTT)?

instruction: What does a single-pulse symbol packet consist of?
input: (Derived from MIL-STD 6011) ``` ----- ``` Symbol Packet A signal element containing either one (single-pulse symbol packet) or two (double-pulse symbol packet) 6.4-microsecond pulses. The single- pulse packet (13 microseconds) consists of a 6.4-microsecond pulse followed by a 6.6-microsecond interval of dead time; the double pulse packet (26 microseconds) consists of two 6.4 microsecond pulses separated and followed by 6.6-microsecond interval of dead time.
output: A single-pulse symbol packet consists of a 6.4-microsecond pulse followed by a 6.6-microsecond interval of dead time.

instruction: What is the purpose of the Synchronization Preamble in JTIDS/MIDS Class 2 Terminal?
input: (System Segment Specification for JTIDS/ MIDS Class 2 Terminal) Synchronization Preamble Sixteen symbol packets that preface each transmitted message to allow for the detection of the beginning of each message and the subsequent decoding of the entire message. (System Segment Specification for JTIDS/MIDS Class 2 Terminal) Systematic Code A code having the characteristic that each information block is encoded into a codeword comprised of "n" symbols in such a way that the first "k" symbols of the codeword are exactly the same as the information block and last "n k" symbols of the codeword are redundant symbols which are functions of the information symbols. (System Segment Specification for JTIDS/MIDS Class 2 Terminal) Tactical Command and Control The exercise of authority and direction by a properly designated commander over assigned forces in the accomplishment of his mission.
output: The Synchronization Preamble is used to detect the beginning of each message and enable the subsequent decoding of the entire message.

(System Segment Specification for JTIDS/MIDS Class 2 Terminal) Tactical Command and Control The exercise of authority and direction by a properly designated commander over assigned forces in the accomplishment of his mission.

instruction: What does the text say about tactical command and control functions?
input: Tactical command and control functions are performed through an arrangement of personnel, equipment, communications, and procedures which are employed by a commander in planning, directing, coordinating, and controlling forces and operations in the accomplishment of his mission. (Joint Pub 1-02) ``` ----- ``` Tactical Command and Control System The facilities, equipment, communications, procedures, and personnel essential to Theater Level and commanders Below-Theater Level for planning, directing, and controlling operations of assigned and attached forces pursuant to the missions assigned and which provide for the conveyance and/or exchange of data and information from one person or force to another. (Joint Pub 1-02) Automated Tactical Command and A command and control system or Control System part thereof which fully manipulates the movement of information from source to user without human intervention.
output: Tactical command and control functions involve planning, directing, coordinating, and controlling forces and operations to accomplish a commander's mission. This is done through an arrangement of personnel, equipment, communications, and procedures.

instruction: What is a tactical command and control system?
input: Tactical command and control functions are performed through an arrangement of personnel, equipment, communications, and procedures which are employed by a commander in planning, directing, coordinating, and controlling forces and operations in the accomplishment of his mission. (Joint Pub 1-02) ``` ----- ``` Tactical Command and Control System The facilities, equipment, communications, procedures, and personnel essential to Theater Level and commanders Below-Theater Level for planning, directing, and controlling operations of assigned and attached forces pursuant to the missions assigned and which provide for the conveyance and/or exchange of data and information from one person or force to another. (Joint Pub 1-02) Automated Tactical Command and A command and control system or Control System part thereof which fully manipulates the movement of information from source to user without human intervention.
output: A tactical command and control system is a facility or part of a command and control system that fully manipulates the movement of information from source to user without human intervention.

instruction: What is automated execution of a decision without human intervention called?
input: (Automated execution of a decision without human intervention is not mandatory.)
output: Automated execution of a decision without human intervention is called an automated decision-making process.

instruction: What is the difference between Semiautomated Tactical Command and Control and Manual Tactical Command and Control?
input: (Joint Pub 1-02) Semiautomated Tactical Command and A machine-aided command and control Control System system wherein human intervention is required in varying degrees to operate the system. (Joint Pub 1 02) Manual Tactical Command and Control A command and control system that System acquires, processes, and passes information generated by man at the source and is received, processed, and acted upon by manual means.
output: Semiautomated Tactical Command and Control requires varying degrees of human intervention to operate, while Manual Tactical Command and Control is operated manually.

instruction: What does a Technical Interface Concepts (TIC) document establish?
input: ``` ----- ``` Technical Interface Concepts (TIC) A document used to establish the conceptual foundation for the design, implementation, and test documentation for the general development of the Joint Chiefs of Staff (JCS) program for ensuring compatibility, interoperability, and operational effectiveness of tactical command and control operational facilities/systems. A TIC identifies: (a) tactical command and control systems and operational facilities of the Services/Agencies. (b) joint interface points, either manual or digital; and (c) inter-Service/Agency information to be exchanged among automated and manual tactical command and control systems.
output: A Technical Interface Concepts (TIC) document establishes the conceptual foundation for the design, implementation, and test documentation for the general development of the Joint Chiefs of Staff (JCS) program for ensuring compatibility, interoperability, and operational effectiveness of tactical command and control operational facilities/systems.

instruction: What does JTIDS/MIDS stand for?

instruction: What is the characteristic of modern armed forces?

output: The characteristic of modern armed forces is that they are dispersed and mobile, providing secure, flexible, and jam-resistant information transfer in real time.

instruction: What are the characteristics of JTIDS/MIDS?
input: JTIDS/MIDS combines characteristics designed to overcome many of the limitations common to existing systems by providing for increased system capacity and coverage, improved connectivity, survivability, jamming resistance, and reduced danger of data loss and data obsolescence.
output: JTIDS/MIDS combines characteristics designed to overcome many of the limitations common to existing systems by providing for increased system capacity and coverage, improved connectivity, survivability, jamming resistance, and reduced danger of data loss and data obsolescence.

instruction: What is the basic element of the JTIDS/MIDS TDMA architecture?
input: The following discussion focuses on the JTIDS/MIDS Time Division Multiple Access (TDMA) architecture (nets and time slots) and the basic features of the JTIDS/MIDS TDMA communication network, including network protocol, transmission procedures, participation groups and messages. 3.3.1 JTIDS/MIDS TDMA ARCHITECTURE The TDMA architecture's basic element is a single communication circuit or net that is shared by many users.
output: The basic element is a single communication circuit or net that is shared by many users.

instruction: What is the net subdivided into?
input: The net is subdivided into time slots that can be assigned to individual JTIDS/MIDS participants (called JTIDS Units (JUs))for transmitting messages.
output: The net is subdivided into time slots.

instruction: What can capacity be expanded further by?
input: Capacity can be expanded further by simultaneous operation on several nets.
output: simultaneous operation on several nets

instruction: What does a JU generally operate on?
input: In general, a JU operates only on a single net at a time but it can switch nets on a time-slot-by-time-slot basis.
output: A JU generally operates on a single net at a time.

instruction: What message packing structures are JUs required to process?
input: All JUs are required to operate in the TDMA network and to process the "Standard Double Pulse (DP)", "Packed-2 Single Pulse (SP)", "Packed-2 DP", "Packed-4 SP" and "Round-Trip-Timing (RTT)" message packing structures (see paragraph 3.3.9). Any JU can transmit Standard DP, Packed-2 SP, Packed-2 DP, Packed-4 SP or RTT message packages in each time slot.
output: JUs are required to process the 'Standard Double Pulse (DP)', 'Packed-2 Single Pulse (SP)', 'Packed-2 DP', 'Packed-4 SP', and 'Round-Trip-Timing (RTT)' message packing structures.

instruction: What is the distinction between the five packing structures?
input: The distinction between the five packing structures lies in the number of pulses transmitted, whether one or two pulses represents a data symbol and, consequently, how much data are transmitted in a time slot.
output: The distinction lies in the number of pulses transmitted, whether one or two pulses represents a data symbol and how much data are transmitted in a time slot.

instruction: What does JUs transmit?
input: JUs can transmit messages in an error correction codeword format in which error correction coding is used by receivers to correct errors caused by noise or jamming.
output: JUs transmit messages in an error correction codeword format.

instruction: What are correctable codewords?
input: All data in correctable codewords ``` ----- ``` are error free. All data in uncorrectable codewords are rejected.
output: All data in correctable codewords are error free.

instruction: What are uncorrectable codewords?
input: All data in correctable codewords ``` ----- ``` are error free. All data in uncorrectable codewords are rejected.
output: All data in uncorrectable codewords are rejected.

instruction: What is Link 16 information transmitted with?
input: Link 16 information is transmitted error correction coded.
output: Error correction coding.

instruction: What is the main topic of the text?
input: Messages also may be transmitted in a non-error coded message packing structure.
output: The text discusses the transmission of messages in a non-error coded message packing structure.

instruction: What can a JU transmit or receive?

output: A JU can transmit or receive one Standard DP, Packed-2 SP, Packed-2 DP, or Packed-4 SP message packing structure in a time slot.

instruction: What does a JU transmit in a time slot?
input: A JU can alternatively transmit one RTT interrogation message in a time slot and then receive an RTT reply to that message in the same time slot. If a JU receives an RTT interrogation message for which it is a valid responder, it will then transmit an RTT reply message in the same time slot.
output: A JU can transmit one RTT interrogation message in a time slot.

instruction: What does a JU receive in the same time slot?
input: A JU can alternatively transmit one RTT interrogation message in a time slot and then receive an RTT reply to that message in the same time slot. If a JU receives an RTT interrogation message for which it is a valid responder, it will then transmit an RTT reply message in the same time slot.
output: A JU receives an RTT reply to the interrogation message it transmitted.

instruction: What happens if a JU receives an RTT interrogation message for which it is a valid responder?
input: A JU can alternatively transmit one RTT interrogation message in a time slot and then receive an RTT reply to that message in the same time slot. If a JU receives an RTT interrogation message for which it is a valid responder, it will then transmit an RTT reply message in the same time slot.
output: If a JU receives an RTT interrogation message for which it is a valid responder, it will transmit an RTT reply message in the same time slot.

instruction: What can a JU switch between?
input: A JU can switch between transmit and receive modes on a time-slot-by-time-slot basis in accordance with its time slot assignments.
output: A JU can switch between transmit and receive modes.

instruction: What is the duration of an epoch?
input: System operation divides time into 12.8-minute intervals, called epochs, with 112.5 epochs per 24-hour day. Each epoch is further divided into 7.8125-millisecond intervals, referred to as time slots (or slots) so that there are 98,304 slots per epoch.
output: An epoch is 12.8 minutes long.

instruction: How many time slots are there in an epoch?

output: There are 98,304 time slots in an epoch.

instruction: What are the time slots organized into?
input: The time slots are organized into three sets (A, B, and C) of 32,768 slots per set. The slots in each set are numbered from 0 to 32,767 so that each slot is identified by its slot number and set, e.g., OA. The slots are distributed in time within each epoch so that time slot "n" of Set A follows time slot "n-1" of Set C and precedes time slot "n" of Set B, where "n" is the set of integers in the sequence 0 to 32,767.
output: The time slots are organized into three sets (A, B, and C).

instruction: What protocols are provided for the establishment and maintenance of the network?

instruction: What is the purpose of synchronization in the context of JUs and TDMA discipline?
input: 3.3.2.1 SYSTEM TIMING AND SYNCHRONIZATION To maintain the TDMA discipline, JUs must be synchronized with a common network time.
output: To maintain the TDMA discipline, JUs must be synchronized with a common network time.

instruction: What is network time?
input: Network time is that time maintained by a particular JU designated as the Network Time Reference (NTR) and is the common time reference with which all other JUs synchronize.
output: Network time is the time maintained by a particular JU designated as the Network Time Reference (NTR) and is the common time reference with which all other JUs synchronize.

instruction: What are the four steps of synchronization?
input: Synchronization consists of making corrections to the clock maintained in each JU and is performed in four steps; (1) initial net entry, (2) coarse synchronization, (3) fine synchronization, and (4) synchronization maintenance.
output: The four steps of synchronization are: 1. Initial net entry, 2. Coarse synchronization, 3. Fine synchronization, and 4. Synchronization maintenance.

instruction: What steps are performed automatically?
input: These steps are performed automatically and depend only on the exchange of messages directly with the NTR or with other JUs that have synchronized with network time.
output: These steps depend only on the exchange of messages directly with the NTR or with other JUs that have synchronized with network time.

instruction: What does JU stand for in the context of the text?
input: Any JU is capable of operating as the NTR. When designated as the NTR, a JU assumes its clock is correct and does not adjust its clock based on network operation (i.e., fine synchronization). There are provisions for an operator-initiated adjustment to system time by the NTR. Such an adjustment is a coordinated operation that involves the simultaneous adjustment of the clocks in the NTR and all other JUs.
output: JU stands for a device capable of operating as the Network Time Reference (NTR) in the text.

instruction: What does the terminal do if it fails to receive a valid net entry message during the time interval?
input: In communication modes 1 and 2, the terminal searches for a net entry message during a time interval that is determined by its amount of uncertainty of the estimate of system time. If the terminal fails to receive ``` ----- ``` a valid net entry message during that interval, it repeats the process, expanding the uncertainty window by a predetermined method.
output: It repeats the process, expanding the uncertainty window by a predetermined method.

instruction: What is the communication mode 4?
input: In communication mode 4, net entry is completed upon the reception of any valid JTIDS/MIDS message.

instruction: What is the purpose of coarse synchronization?
input: 3.3.2.3 COARSE SYNCHRONIZATION To achieve coarse synchronization, a JU must adjust its clock so that it can identify time slots (set and number) and identify the start of time slots with sufficient accuracy to receive any message and perform the active mode of fine synchronization.
output: To achieve coarse synchronization, a JU must adjust its clock so that it can identify time slots (set and number) and identify the start of time slots with sufficient accuracy to receive any message and perform the active mode of fine synchronization.

instruction: What is not permitted to transmit until it has achieved fine synchronization?

instruction: What is coarse synchronization?
input: Coarse synchronization is performed by receiving an error-free Initial Entry message and using the time of arrival of the Initial Entry message to adjust the JU's clock.
output: Coarse synchronization is the process of adjusting the clock of a Juno Unit (JU) by receiving an error-free Initial Entry message and using the time of arrival of this message.

instruction: What is the purpose of the RTT Interrogation message?
input: The interrogating JU transmits an RTT Interrogation message and determines the associated RTT Reply message's Time Of Arrival (TOAR). The interrogating JU then computes its clock correction based on the measured value of TOAR and the value of TOAI included in the RTT Reply message.
output: The RTT Interrogation message is used by the interrogating JU to transmit and determine the associated RTT Reply message's Time Of Arrival (TOAR).

instruction: What is an interrogation message transmitted on the net?
input: An interrogation message is transmitted on the net whose net number is equal to the highest time quality contained in any received position report. JUs with a time quality equal to the time quality specified in the RTT Interrogation message respond with an RTT Reply message on the net number equal to the time quality.
output: An interrogation message is transmitted on the net whose net number is equal to the highest time quality contained in any received position report.

instruction: What is the purpose of the passive mode in a JU?
input: ``` ----- ``` 3.3.2.4.2 PASSIVE MODE In the passive mode a JU simultaneously adjusts its clock and its estimate of own position (see paragraph 3.3.8) until it determines that its clock is operating within the required tolerance.

instruction: What does the JU measure?
input: The JU measures the Time Of Arrival (TOA) of error-free PPLI messages from selected JUs and combines multiple TOA measurements through a recursive filter process to determine corrections for its clock and adjustment to its own-position estimate.
output: The JU measures the Time Of Arrival (TOA) of error-free PPLI messages.

instruction: What are required for the passive mode?

instruction: What is the purpose of the fine synchronization process in JUs?
input: 3.3.2.4.3 SYNCHRONIZATION MAINTENANCE After achieving fine synchronization JUs continue to monitor clock performance through the outputs of the filter process and perform the fine synchronization process (active or passive) as necessary to maintain synchronization with system time.
output: The fine synchronization process in JUs is used to maintain synchronization with system time. It continues to monitor clock performance through the outputs of the filter process and performs the fine synchronization process (active or passive) as necessary.

instruction: What happens if clock errors exceed predefined limits?
input: If clock errors exceed predefined limits, a JU inhibits message transmission (except RTT Interrogation messages) and initiates the fine synchronization process.

instruction: What is a variable time delay in the start of transmission in a time slot?
input: A variable time delay in the start of transmission in a time slot.
output: A variable time delay in the start of transmission in a time slot refers to a situation where the transmission of data packets is delayed by a certain amount of time before they are sent out. This delay can vary depending on various factors such as network conditions, load, and other factors affecting the network's performance. The purpose of introducing this delay is to ensure that the network can handle incoming data packets efficiently and avoid congestion or packet loss. By introducing a variable time delay, the network can adjust the timing of packet transmission based on current network conditions, thereby optimizing overall network performance.

instruction: What are the types of messages encoded using Reed-Solomon code?
input: 3.3.3.2.3 FORWARD ERROR CORRECTION ENCODING The header word, fixed and variable format messages, and selected free-text messages are encoded using a Reed-Solomon code.
output: The header word, fixed and variable format messages, and selected free-text messages are encoded using a Reed-Solomon code.

instruction: What is the Reed-Solomon code?
input: The Reed-Solomon code is a 32-ary cyclic block code in the class of generalized Bose-ChaudhuriHocquenguem (BCH) codes. The Reed-Solomon encoding process converts the 35bit header word into a (16, 7) Reed-Solomon codeword. The (16, 7) codeword contains 16 five-bit bytes, of which seven bytes contain data (35 bits of header) and nine bytes contain parity bits. The 75-bit words comprising messages are individually encoded as (31, 15) Reed-Solomon codewords. The (31, 15) codeword contains 31 five-bit bytes, of which 15 bytes contain data and 16 bytes contain parity bits. The (31, 15) and (16, 7) codewords can be encoded and decoded by the same logic.
output: A 32-ary cyclic block code in the class of generalized Bose-Chaudhuri-Hocquenghem (BCH) codes.

instruction: How does the Reed-Solomon encoding process convert a 35-bit header word into a (16, 7) Reed-Solomon codeword?

The (16, 7) codeword contains 16 five-bit bytes, of which seven bytes contain data (35 bits of header) and nine bytes contain parity bits. The 75-bit words comprising messages are individually encoded as (31, 15) Reed-Solomon codewords. The (31, 15) codeword contains 31 five-bit bytes, of which 15 bytes contain data and 16 bytes contain parity bits. The (31, 15) and (16, 7) codewords can be encoded and decoded by the same logic.
output: The 35-bit header word is converted into a (16, 7) Reed-Solomon codeword, which contains 16 five-bit bytes, of which seven bytes contain data (35 bits of header) and nine bytes contain parity bits.

instruction: What is the purpose of CCSK encoding in the context of the text?
input: 3.3.3.2.5 CYCLIC CODE SHIFT KEYING ENCODING CCSK encoding is applied to the five-bit bytes comprising the Reed-Solomon encoded header word and message(s) after the bytes have been interleaved (if required). Table 3.3-1 illustrates the relationship between the five-bit bytes and the CCSK codewords. The 32-bit CCSK codeword for a byte is generated by left-cyclic shifting the initial CCSK codeword (So) n times, where n equals the value (0-31) of the byte being encoded.

instruction: What are the two types of transmission symbol packets?
input: 11111 S31 = 00111110011101001000010101110110 3.3.3.2.6 TRANSMISSION SYMBOL PACKET GENERATION The CCSK codewords are converted to one of two types (DP or SP) of transmission symbol packets (also called symbol packets) illustrated in Figure 3.3-5. In the DP symbol packet the same CCSK codeword is applied to both pulses. instruction: What is the method used for modulating the carrier frequency in the pulse?
input: The transmitted pulse is formed by continuous phase shift modulation (CPSM) of the carrier frequency at a 5-megabit-per-second rate using the 32-bit pulse sequence as the modulating signal. CPSM, also known as minimum frequency shift keying, can be viewed as phase coherent Frequency Shift Keying (FSK) modulation. Viewed as an FSK modulation, CPSM is represented by a phase coherent binary FSK signal between two frequencies, F1 and F2, with separation between them equal to 1/2T, where T = the digit duration of 200 nanoseconds, as illustrated in Figure 3.3-6.
output: Continuous phase shift modulation (CPSM) of the carrier frequency at a 5-megabit-per-second rate using a 32-bit pulse sequence as the modulating signal.

instruction: What are the three operator selectable transmit modes available to a JU?
input: 3.3.5 TRANSMIT MODES Three operator selectable transmit modes are available to a JU. The selected transmit mode determines the conditions under which the JU may transmit messages and is set independently for each JU. The transmit modes are discussed in the following paragraphs. 3.3.5.1 NORMAL MODE In the normal mode, a JU achieves and maintains fine synchronization, either passively or actively, and then transmits messages unconditionally, subject only to the constraints of its assigned transmit time slots and message exchange protocol. ``` ----- ``` 3.3.5.2 POLLING MODE In the polling mode, a JU achieves and maintains fine synchronization either passively or actively. A JU in the polling mode transmits fixed and variable format messages only when required to transmit (1) a message in response to a received Communication Control message addressed to the JU, and (2) an operator or machine acknowledgment message.
output: The three operator selectable transmit modes available to a JU are Normal Mode, Polling Mode, and Automatic Request Mode.

input: Data messages include those being originated at the transmitting terminal and those being relayed by the transmitting terminal. In addition to the synchronization preamble and time refinement/pulses, data messages contain a header plus the information bearing portion of the message.
output: Data messages include those being originated at the transmitting terminal and those being relayed by the transmitting terminal. In addition to the synchronization preamble and time refinement/pulses, data messages contain a header plus the information bearing portion of the message.

instruction: What are the two main concepts being discussed in the text?
input: These data messages are further distinguished by packing structures and data formats as indicated in Figure 3.3-3. The packing structures define the amount and symbol redundancy of information that can be conveyed in a message transmission, while the data formats define the structure or formatting of the data themselves.
output: The two main concepts being discussed in the text are packing structures and data formats.

instruction: What are the four message packing structures used for data messages?
input: The following paragraphs discuss the packing structures, data formats, and headers of JTIDS/MIDS data messages. 3.3.9.1 DATA MESSAGE PACKING STRUCTURES FORMATS Data messages are transmitted in one of four message packing structures: Standard DP, Packed-2 SP, Packed-2 DP, and Packed-4 SP.
output: The four message packing structures used for data messages are: Standard DP, Packed-2 SP, Packed-2 DP, and Packed-4 SP.

instruction: What is the format of the header word?
input: In each of these formats, the header word (described more fully in paragraph 3.3.9.3) is sent as a 16-symbol, double pulse per symbol Reed-Solomon codeword.
output: The header word is sent as a 16-symbol, double pulse per symbol Reed-Solomon codeword.

instruction: What is the distinction between the four structures?
input: The distinction between the four structures lies in the number of data symbols transmitted to convey information and whether the symbols are SP or DP (see paragraph 3.3.3.2.6).
output: The distinction lies in the number of data symbols transmitted to convey information and whether the symbols are SP or DP.

instruction: What is the information bearing portion of Standard DP JTIDS/MIDS message packing structures?
input: The following paragraphs describe the four message packing structures in more detail. 3.3.9.1.1 STANDARD DP MESSAGE PACKING STRUCTURE The information bearing portion of Standard DP JTIDS/MIDS message packing structures consists of 93 symbols.
output: It consists of 93 symbols.

instruction: What are the symbols used for?
input: These symbols can convey three (31, 15) Reed-Solomon codewords representing 225 bits of coded information or, alternatively, 465 bits of uncoded data.
output: They can convey three Reed-Solomon codewords representing 225 bits of coded information or 465 bits of uncoded data.

instruction: What does the Standard DP message packing structure contain?
input: Thus, the Standard DP message packing structure contains 32 pulses in the synchronization preamble, 8 pulses in the TR segment, and 218 pulses corresponding to 109 DP symbols used to convey the header plus data.
output: The Standard DP message packing structure contains 32 pulses in the synchronization preamble, 8 pulses in the TR segment, and 218 pulses corresponding to 109 DP symbols used to convey the header plus data.

instruction: What are the three types of message types in JTIDS/MIDS data messages?
input: 3.3.9.2 MESSAGE TYPES JTIDS/MIDS data messages are further characterized by whether the underlying information transmitted is arranged in a fixed, predefined format (fixed format); a variable, but predefined format (variable format); or in a nonpredefined format (free text format). These message types are described in the following paragraphs.
output: The three types are fixed format, variable format, and free text format.

instruction: What is a fixed format message?
input: 3.3.9.2.1 FIXED FORMAT MESSAGES A fixed format message includes up to three, six, or twelve 75-bit words (70 data bits/word), depending on the packing format and whether the DP or SP transmission symbol packet is used.
output: A fixed format message includes up to three, six, or twelve 75-bit words (70 data bits/word), depending on the packing format and whether the DP or SP transmission symbol packet is used.

instruction: What is predefined in each word?
input: The format and sequence of data fields in each word are predefined (see section 5).
output: The format and sequence of data fields are predefined.

instruction: What does a message consist of?
input: A message is composed of an initial word and may include extension and/or continuation words. The availability of data and the applicable message exchange protocol define the combination of extension and/or continuation words included in a message.
output: A message is composed of an initial word and may include extension and/or continuation words.

instruction: What are the basic functions of these words?

instruction: What does the initial word identify in a message?
input: The initial word identifies the message and the sum of the extension and continuation words following the initial word, and it contains the basic data included in the message.
output: The initial word identifies the message.

instruction: What is the text about?
input: b.
output: The text is about a specific instruction or task.

instruction: What are extension words?
input: Extension Words. The extension words contain additional data that are normally included in the message. Extension words need not be transmitted in a message, but, if they are transmitted, they must be transmitted in serial order following the initial word.
output: Extension words contain additional data that are normally included in the message.

instruction: What are continuation words?
input: c. Continuation Words. The continuation words contain amplifying (e.g., optional) data that are included in the message as required by the message exchange protocol and the availability of information. If extension words are transmitted, continuation words must be transmitted following all extension words.
output: Continuation words contain amplifying data that are included in the message as required by the message exchange protocol and the availability of information.

instruction: What does a JU transmit in a single Standard DP, Packed-2 SP, Packed-2 DP, and Packed-4 SP message packing structure?

instruction: What must be transmitted in proper sequence in a single time slot?

instruction: What can be transmitted in a time slot?

instruction: What is a VMF?

output: A VMF is a variable length string of fields formatted into 75-bit words for transmission.

instruction: What can vary in individual words in a message?

instruction: What can be predefined in a VMF?

instruction: What is a track number (TN)?
input: Representative FJU Link Configurations ----- ###### 4.1.3 TRACK/ADDRESS NUMBERING A track number (TN) is used to provide a common reference number for information and directives exchanged within the interface. The reference numbers are used for both digital and voice communications to denote all IUs and/or tactical information reports, e.g., tracks. For the purpose of TN assignment, tactical information reporting includes reference numbers assigned to all tracks, strobes, bearing lines, and points exchanged on the interface.
output: A track number (TN) is used to provide a common reference number for information and directives exchanged within the interface.

instruction: What is the structure of the 19-bit Link 16 TN?
input: The 19-bit Link 16 TN is composed of two 5 bit groups followed by three 3-bit groups, for a total of five characters.
output: It is composed of two 5 bit groups followed by three 3-bit groups, for a total of five characters.

instruction: What does the 5-bit groups have a range of meaning?
input: The 5-bit groups have a range of meaning of 0 through 7 or A through Z, less I and O. The 3-bit groups are always numeric, 0 through 7.
output: 0 through 7 or A through Z, less I and O.

instruction: What are the 3-bit groups always numeric?
input: The 5-bit groups have a range of meaning of 0 through 7 or A through Z, less I and O. The 3-bit groups are always numeric, 0 through 7.

instruction: What are the differences between 15-bit JU addresses and 15 least significant bits (LSBs) of the 19-bit TN?
input: Due to this composition, the 15-bit JU addresses are not the same as the 15 least significant bits (LSBs) of the 19-bit TN, but the 12-bit Link 11/11B TNs are the same as the 12 LSBs of the 19-bit TN. For display and database purposes, a 15-bit address is the same TN as the 19-bit TN composed of the same octal numbers. The purely numeric 5-digit Link 16 addresses and TNs are embedded between sequences containing 5-character alphanumeric TNs.

instruction: What is the purpose of allocating TNs below the octal number 07777 in a Link 11/11B interface?
input: In an interface with Link 11 and/or 11B units, the block of TNs allocated as JU addresses should be below the octal number 07777 to ensure that a JU has one and only one TN throughout a Link 11/11B/16 interface. instruction: What is AN?

instruction: What are the addresses assigned for units operating on Link 11 and Link 11B?
input: Addresses for units operating on Link 11 (PUs, FPUs, FJUAs, and FJUABs) shall be assigned from the block of octal numbers 00001 through 00076. Addresses for units operating on Link 11B (RUs, FRUs, and FJUBs) shall be assigned addresses from the block of octal numbers 00100 through 00175. C[2] JU addresses shall be assigned from the blocks of octal numbers 00001 through 00076, 00100 through 00175, 00200 through 07776, and 10000 through 77776. To exchange addressed messages with Link 11/11B units, a C[2] JU must be assigned an address from the blocks of octal numbers 00001 through 00076 and 00100 through 00175. Addresses for nonC[2] JUs shall be assigned from the blocks of octal numbers 00200 through 07776 and 10000 through 77776.
output: Addresses for units operating on Link 11 (PUs, FPUs, FJUAs, and FJUABs) shall be assigned from the block of octal numbers 00001 through 00076. Addresses for units operating on Link 11B (RUs, FRUs, and FJUBs) shall be assigned addresses from the block of octal numbers 00100 through 00175.

instruction: What is the purpose of allocating blocks of contiguous numbers to each interfacing system?
input: 4.1.3.3 TRACK NUMBER ALLOCATION Based upon each interfacing system's requirements, blocks of contiguous numbers shall be allocated to each system for use in reporting tactical information.
output: The purpose is for use in reporting tactical information.

instruction: What can a system do with its block(s)?
input: A system may subdivide its block(s) for allocation to subordinate units.
output: A system may subdivide its block(s) for allocation to subordinate units.

instruction: What is the purpose of allocating a larger number of TNs than its local track capacity?
input: Each unit should be allocated a larger number of TNs than its local track capacity to provide the capability to report tracks when some of its TNs are being used by other units as a result of shifts in reporting responsibility (R[2]).
output: To provide the capability to report tracks when some of its TNs are being used by other units as a result of shifts in reporting responsibility.

instruction: What are TN blocks assigned to?

TN blocks are assigned to C[2] JUs from the octal numbers 00200 through 07776 (low TNs), 10000 through 77776 (high TNs), and alphanumeric (octal) block 0A000 through ZZ777 (high TNs).
output: TN blocks are assigned to PUs, FPUs, RUs, FRUs, FJUAs, FJUBs, and FJUABs.

instruction: What is the limit for the block of TNs allocated to C[2] Units for reporting tracks, points, or lines of bearing (LOBs)?
input: In an interface with Link 11 or Link 11B units, the block of TNs allocated to C[2] Units for the reporting of tracks, points, or lines of bearing (LOBs) should be limited (when possible) to values below the octal number 07777 so that the TN can be equated to the Link 11/11B TN.
output: The limit should be below the octal number 07777 so that the TN can be equated to the Link 11/11B TN.

instruction: What is the significance of using TN values greater than the octal number 07777?
input: When track volume requires ----- ###### additional numbers, TN values greater than the octal number 07777 may be used but the equating of TNs will not be possible.
output: When track volume requires additional numbers, TN values greater than the octal number 07777 may be used but the equating of TNs will not be possible.

instruction: What is the recommended limit for TN block values in a mixed IJMS/Link 16 environment?
input: In a mixed IJMS/Link 16 environment, the TN block(s) should be limited (when possible) to values below the octal number 77777 so that the TN can be equated to the Link 16/IJMS TN.
output: The TN block(s) should be limited (when possible) to values below the octal number 77777 so that the TN can be equated to the Link 16/IJMS TN.

instruction: What is the significance of using Track Numbers greater than 77777 octal?
input: If additional TNs are required, Track Numbers greater than 77777 octal may be used but the equating of TNs will not be possible.
output: They may be used for additional TNs, but equating of TNs will not be possible.

instruction: What must systems operating on more than one data link do to equate TNs between the links?
input: Systems operating on more than one data link shall, equate TNs between the links, such that the decimal value representation will be the same. To accomplish this, systems must be assigned track blocks among multiple links to allow for equating of TNs.
output: Systems operating on more than one data link shall equate TNs between the links, such that the decimal value representation will be the same.

instruction: What are the two instances where track numbers cannot be limited?
input: It is understood that there will be instances that will preclude limiting track numbers. It is also understood that even if track numbers are limited there will be instances where a unit will be unable to equate TNs because of a specific TN in use. In both of these cases, TNs will not be able to be equated.
output: The text does not specify the two instances where track numbers cannot be limited.

instruction: What are the specified ranges from which C[2] JUs can accept noncontiguous blocks of TNs?
input: C[2] JUs shall be capable of accepting a minimum of two separate noncontiguous blocks of TNs, including a low TN block and a high TN block, from any of these specified ranges.
output: The specified ranges are not explicitly stated in the text.

instruction: What is the purpose of the Data Forwarding TN block in an FJU?
input: An FJU shall also be capable of accepting a Data Forwarding TN block in the range 00200-07776 for use in TN association. The Data Forwarding TN block is not required to be contiguous with or a subset of the low TN block allocated to the FJU's host IU.
output: The Data Forwarding TN block is used in TN association.

instruction: What is the purpose of assigning a specific TN to each interfacing unit on Link 16?
input: 4.1.3.4 ADDRESS ASSIGNMENT Each interfacing unit on Link 16 shall be assigned a specific TN for use as its address prior to joining the interface. An interfacing unit on Link 16 shall be capable of accepting any assigned address within the range of TNs allocated as addresses.
output: The purpose of assigning a specific TN to each interfacing unit on Link 16 is to provide a unique address for each unit, allowing it to join the interface and communicate effectively.

instruction: What is the purpose of track number assignment?
input: 4.1.3.5 TRACK NUMBER ASSIGNMENT Each subset of tactical information including air tracks, surface (maritime) tracks, subsurface (maritime) tracks, land (ground) tracks, bearings, fixes, and/or points, that is originated by a unit and reported within the interface ----- ###### shall be assigned a TN from the block(s) allocated to that system or unit.
output: Track number assignment is used to identify and manage subsets of tactical information, including air tracks, surface (maritime) tracks, subsurface (maritime) tracks, land (ground) tracks, bearings, fixes, and/or points.

instruction: What capability do C[2] units have?
input: In addition, all C[2] units shall have the capability to manually assign individual TNs outside their allocated block.
output: C[2] units have the capability to manually assign individual TNs outside their allocated block.

instruction: What is the requirement for track initiation and TN assignment?
input: Each system shall ensure that two different tracks are not reported using the same TN, and that multiple TNs are not assigned to the same track. Each system may establish its own criteria for the initiation of tracks and for TN assignment and reporting within the interface.
output: Each system may establish its own criteria for the initiation of tracks and for TN assignment and reporting within the interface.

instruction: What does the text say about TN accountability?
input: An SU shall be assigned a TN from the parent IU or unit TN allocation. 4.1.3.6 TRACK NUMBER ACCOUNTABILITY Each C[2] IU shall be responsible for maintaining accountability of TNs.
output: The text states that each C[2] IU is responsible for maintaining accountability of TNs.

instruction: What is the purpose of assigning a TN for reporting tactical information?
input: Once a TN has been assigned for reporting tactical information, that TN shall be associated with that track data for as long as the data are reported within the interface, regardless of which unit is reporting the data.
output: To associate it with the track data for as long as the data are reported within the interface, regardless of which unit is reporting the data.

instruction: What is the process for C[2] JU to assign TNs?
input: Each C[2] JU shall normally assign TNs from its allocated block(s), cycling through the block(s) and skipping those numbers known to be in use.
output: C[2] JUs normally assign TNs from their allocated blocks, cycling through the blocks and skipping numbers known to be in use.

instruction: What is the purpose of reassigning TNs after the IU has cycled through the block(s) for the first time?
input: After an IU has cycled through the block(s) for the first time, TNs must be reassigned again, skipping those in current use, in such a way to preclude the confusion that can occur when the reporting of specific data is terminated and the TN is immediately reassigned.
output: The purpose is to preclude confusion that can occur when the reporting of specific data is terminated and the TN is immediately reassigned.

instruction: What is the rule for reassignment of low TNs when both low and high TN blocks are allocated?
input: When both a low TN and a high TN block are allocated, the low TNs shall be eligible for reassignment when the upper limit of the low TN block is reached. Normally, the high TNs will be assigned only when no low TN is eligible for assignment or reassignment.
output: When the upper limit of the low TN block is reached, low TNs become eligible for reassignment.

instruction: Under what conditions will high TNs be assigned?
input: When both a low TN and a high TN block are allocated, the low TNs shall be eligible for reassignment when the upper limit of the low TN block is reached. Normally, the high TNs will be assigned only when no low TN is eligible for assignment or reassignment.
output: High TNs will be assigned only when no low TN is eligible for assignment or reassignment.

instruction: What does the text say about resolving duplicate track number reporting?
input: The same TN is being used by two or more units to report two or more different tracks. ----- ###### 4.1.3.7 RESOLUTION OF DUPLICATE TRACK NUMBER The resolution of duplicate TN reporting requires that agreement be reached via voice coordination among the conflicting units as to which track will carry the TN in use.
output: The resolution of duplicate track number (TN) reporting requires agreement via voice coordination among conflicting units. The conflicting units must decide which track will carry the TN in use.

instruction: What is data registration?
input: 4.1.4 DATA REGISTRATION Data registration is a condition of correct relative alignment between local and remote track positional data.
output: Data registration is a condition of correct relative alignment between local and remote track positional data.

instruction: What does the text involve?
input: It involves measuring, computing, converting, transforming and adjusting positional data.
output: Measuring, computing, converting, transforming and adjusting positional data.

instruction: What is the condition for optimal interface data registration?
input: Optimum interface data registration occurs when all the IUs hold their locally derived track positional data at the same geodetic position as the remote positional data for the same interface tracks.
output: Optimal interface data registration occurs when all the IUs hold their locally derived track positional data at the same geodetic position as the remote positional data for the same interface tracks.

instruction: What is geodetic position defined in terms of?
input: Geodetic position is defined in terms of latitude, longitude, and altitude in reference to an earth model.
output: Latitude, longitude, and altitude in reference to an earth model.

instruction: What is the fundamental operation of an interface?

instruction: What must IUs do with the reported tracks?

instruction: What is the correlation process?
input: The correlation process is compounded as either the remote or local positional errors increase.
output: The correlation process is compounded as either the remote or local positional errors increase.

instruction: What are the two types of track positional errors mentioned?

instruction: What are geodetic position errors?
input: 4.1.4.1.1 GEODETIC POSITION ERRORS Geodetic position errors are associated with each JU's ability to determine its position in terms of geodetic latitude, longitude, and altitude.
output: Geodetic position errors are associated with each JU's ability to determine its position in terms of geodetic latitude, longitude, and altitude.

instruction: What are the two positions of a JU mentioned in the text?
input: They are defined as the difference between the JU's reported position and the JU's position relative to the reference spheroid (normally World Geodetic System 84 (WGS-84)).
output: The two positions are the JU's reported position and the JU's position relative to the reference spheroid (normally World Geodetic System 84 (WGS-84)).

instruction: What is the difference between the two positions of a JU?
input: They are defined as the difference between the JU's reported position and the JU's position relative to the reference spheroid (normally World Geodetic System 84 (WGS-84)).
output: The difference is defined as the difference between the JU's reported position and its position relative to the reference spheroid.

instruction: How do Stationary JUs determine geodetic position?
input: Stationary JUs usually determine geodetic position through site surveys which are accomplished prior to link participation. Moving JUs derive geodetic position in real-time from the JU's navigation systems and other navigation aids (e.g., OMEGA, Tactical Air Navigation (TACAN), Global Positioning System (GPS), etc.).
output: Stationary JUs determine geodetic position through site surveys which are accomplished prior to link participation.

instruction: How do Moving JUs determine geodetic position?
input: Stationary JUs usually determine geodetic position through site surveys which are accomplished prior to link participation. Moving JUs derive geodetic position in real-time from the JU's navigation systems and other navigation aids (e.g., OMEGA, Tactical Air Navigation (TACAN), Global Positioning System (GPS), etc.).
output: Moving JUs derive geodetic position in real-time from the JU's navigation systems and other navigation aids (e.g., OMEGA, Tactical Air Navigation (TACAN), Global Positioning System (GPS), etc.).

instruction: What is geodetic registration?
input: Description of Geodetic Coordinate System ----- ###### 4.1.4.2.1 GEODETIC REGISTRATION Geodetic registration is defined as a process in which a JU monitors its reported geodetic positional data and periodically adjusts this geodetic data with information derived from active participation in the JTIDS/MIDS Relative Navigation function. Geodetic registration begins with a capability of the JU to determine and maintain accurate positional coordinates in terms of geodetic latitude, longitude, and altitude.

instruction: What is the purpose of active participation in the JTIDS/MIDS Relative Navigation function?
input: Monitoring of relative geodetic position is provided by active participation in the JTIDS/MIDS Relative Navigation function during netted operation. Through active participation in the JTIDS/MIDS Relative Navigation function, highly accurate adjustments to the reported geodetic position are obtainable. The JTIDS/MIDS terminal will provide Relative Navigation adjustments to the host platform in terms of latitude correction (LATC), longitude correction (LONC), and altitude correction (HC).

instruction: What conditions must be met for data protected by the SPI set to value 1 to be transmitted on Link 16?
input: Data protected by the SPI set to value 1 shall be transmitted on Link 16 only if the terminal or other communication path is operating in a secure mode. c. Data protected by the SPI set to value 1 shall not be transmitted on Link 16 if there are any units on the interface which are unable to protect the data according to its classification. 4.1.6.2 FORWARDING OF DATA PROTECTED BY THE SPI Data which is protected by the SPI set to value 1 shall not be forwarded onto unsecured links or voice circuit. A unit which is forwarding Link 16 to Link 11 shall adhere to the constraints for data protected by the SPI, in accordance with the procedures in MIL-STD 6016, Appendix C. 4.1.6.3 SECURITY FILTERING All units which are capable of transmitting data protected by the SPI shall also implement a security transmit filter to inhibit such transmissions.
output: Data protected by the SPI set to value 1 shall be transmitted on Link 16 only if the terminal or other communication path is operating in a secure mode, and if there are no units on the interface which are unable to protect the data according to its classification.

instruction: What does the R/C field in the OM specify?
input: 4.1.7.1 ORIGINAL MESSAGE An R/C field in the OM specifies whether a response message is to be returned to the originator. If the R/C field is set to value 0, then a response message is required. If the R/C field is set to value 5, then only a machine receipt (MR) message and/or automatic computer generated response is required. If the R/C field is set to value 1, then no response message is required.
output: Whether a response message is to be returned to the originator.

instruction: What are the possible values for the R/C field and what do they mean?

If the R/C field is set to value 1, then no response message is required.

instruction: What is the R/C field of an OM addressed to more than one unit set to?

instruction: What is a machine receipt message?
input: 4.1.7.2 MACHINE RECEIPT A machine receipt message has the R/C field set to value 2 and shall be transmitted once by an addressed terminal upon receipt of either a valid OM ----- ###### with the R/C field set to value 0 or 5 or upon receipt of a response message with the R/C field set to a value greater than 2.

instruction: What is a machine receipt in network management messages?
input: In the network management messages, the machine receipt is equivalent to a WILCO message. Therefore, a machine receipt for a network management OM shall only be sent if the addressed terminal can accept and execute the actions specified in the OM.
output: A machine receipt is equivalent to a WILCO message in network management messages. It is sent only if the addressed terminal can accept and execute the actions specified in the OM.

instruction: What fields should be set in the machine receipt message?
input: The machine receipt message shall be transmitted in the time slot specified by the Recurrence Rate, Receipt/Compliance field of the message it is responding to. The machine receipt message shall be identical to the message it is responding to except in the Source TN; Relayed Transmission Indicator; Message Length Indicator; Addressee TN; R/C; and Recurrence Rate, Receipt/Compliance fields. The Recurrence Rate, Receipt Compliance field shall be set to the No Statement value in all machine receipt messages. A response message with the R/C field set to a value greater than 2 may be transmitted in lieu of the machine receipt message.

instruction: What is a response message with the R/C field set to a value greater than 2 used for?
input: The machine receipt message shall be transmitted in the time slot specified by the Recurrence Rate, Receipt/Compliance field of the message it is responding to. The machine receipt message shall be identical to the message it is responding to except in the Source TN; Relayed Transmission Indicator; Message Length Indicator; Addressee TN; R/C; and Recurrence Rate, Receipt/Compliance fields. The Recurrence Rate, Receipt Compliance field shall be set to the No Statement value in all machine receipt messages. A response message with the R/C field set to a value greater than 2 may be transmitted in lieu of the machine receipt message.
output: A response message with the R/C field set to a value greater than 2 may be transmitted in lieu of the machine receipt message.

instruction: What must be transmitted in lieu of a machine receipt message if the addressed terminal cannot accept and execute the action specified in a network management OM?
input: A CANTPRO message must be transmitted in lieu of a machine receipt message if the addressed terminal cannot accept and execute the action specified in a network management OM. 4.1.7.3 CANNOT PROCESS RESPONSE An appropriate CANTPRO response message shall be transmitted automatically by an addressed unit upon receipt of an OM with the R/C field set to value 0 or value 5 if the message cannot be processed. The R/C field of the CANTPRO response message shall indicate the reason the message cannot be processed. This is an automatic computer generated response and the operator need not be aware that any order has been received or that the CANTPRO response has been generated. The CANTPRO response message shall be identical to the OM it is responding to except in the Source TN; Relayed Transmission Indicator; Addressee TN; R/C; and Recurrence Rate, Receipt/Compliance fields.
output: A CANTPRO message must be transmitted.
