instruction: What is important to Network Management?
input: Of importance to the task of Network Management is the fact that Link 16 participation requires that specific technical functions be implemented by all JUs on the network.
output: Link 16 participation requires that specific technical functions be implemented by all JUs on the network.

instruction: What is the minimum implementation requirement?
input: The requirements of minimum implementation will, by necessity, use a portion of the total JTIDS/MIDS network capacity. 4.2.3.4 RESPONSE TIME JTIDS/MIDS capacity assignments may be driven by response time requirements.
output: The minimum implementation requirement uses a portion of the total JTIDS/MIDS network capacity.

instruction: What is the purpose of JTIDS/MIDS capacity assignments?
input: The requirements of minimum implementation will, by necessity, use a portion of the total JTIDS/MIDS network capacity. 4.2.3.4 RESPONSE TIME JTIDS/MIDS capacity assignments may be driven by response time requirements.
output: JTIDS/MIDS capacity assignments may be driven by response time requirements.

instruction: What is response time?
input: Response time is a term used to characterize delay performance of a system given a set of inputs or stimuli. Response time is therefore dependent on the specific messages entering the system and the "extent of the system."
output: Response time is a term used to characterize delay performance of a system given a set of inputs or stimuli.

instruction: What does "extent of the system" include?
input: The "extent of the system" may include the JU, or may encompass the originator and recipient (end-to-end process) including both people and equipment.
output: The "extent of the system" may include the JU, or may encompass the originator and recipient (end-to-end process) including both people and equipment.

instruction: What is the response time defined as?
input: Response times are defined below: ----- ###### a. JU Response Time.
output: Response times are defined below: ----- ###### a. JU Response Time.

instruction: What is the time from new information availability at the JU to the transmission of the information on the link?
input: The time from new information availability at the JU to the transmission of the information on the link.
output: The time from new information availability at the JU to the transmission of the information on the link is not explicitly stated in the given text.

instruction: What is the purpose of this time definition?
input: This time is defined for each message in Table 4.1-3. b. Terminal Response Time.
output: To define a specific time for each message in Table 4.1-3, specifically for the Terminal Response Time.

instruction: What is the time from new information availability at the terminal to the transmission of the information on the link?
input: The time from new information availability at the terminal to the transmission of the information on the link.
output: The time from new information availability at the terminal to the transmission of the information on the link is called latency.

instruction: What is the Terminal Response Time?
input: The JU Response Time is made up of the Terminal Response Time and the platform system response time. For purposes of platform system implementation, the Terminal Response Time begins when the data are available at the output interface of the platform system and ends when the message signal has been emitted on the source antenna.
output: The Terminal Response Time begins when the data are available at the output interface of the platform system and ends when the message signal has been emitted on the source antenna.

instruction: What are the two types of time mentioned in the text?
input: This time can be divided into necessary processing time and time to availability of the next transmission time slot.
output: The two types of time mentioned are necessary processing time and time to availability of the next transmission time slot.

instruction: What is the necessary processing time?
input: The necessary processing time is 100 msec (approximately 13 time slots).
output: 100 msec (approximately 13 time slots)

instruction: What is the time to the availability of the next transmission time slot dependent on?
input: The time to the availability of the next transmission time slot is a function of Network Management decisions.
output: Network Management decisions.

instruction: What are the principal determining factors for access rate and access mode?
input: The access rate and access mode are principal determining factors.
output: The access rate and access mode are principal determining factors.

instruction: What is the main focus of the given text?
input: c. End-to-End Response Time.
output: The main focus of the given text is on the end-to-end response time.

instruction: What is the time from new information availability at the source JU to the reception of the message at the destination JU?
input: The time from new information availability at the source JU to the reception of the message at the destination JU.
output: The time from new information availability at the source JU to the reception of the message at the destination JU is not specified in the given text.

instruction: What is the item of concern in terms of operational requirements?
input: In terms of operational requirements, the End-to-End Response Time is the item of concern.
output: End-to-End Response Time

instruction: What is the response time made up of?
input: This response time is made up of the JU Response Time and the transmission time. Transmission time varies with the transmission path which, to the extent it is controllable, depends on Network Management decisions.
output: The response time is made up of the JU Response Time and the transmission time.

instruction: What are the principal determining factors of relay units?
input: The number of relays and the offset delay at each relay unit are the principal determining factors.
output: The number of relays and the offset delay at each relay unit are the principal determining factors.

instruction: What does the Network Manager consider when calculating End-to-End Response Time?
input: The Network Manager must consider the delays resulting from access rate, access mode, and relay delay in arriving at an End-to-End Response Time that is operationally acceptable. The Network Manager uses Terminal Response Time to estimate the time slot capacity (time slots per second) needed to meet End-to-End Response Time requirements.
output: The Network Manager considers access rate, access mode, and relay delay.

instruction: How does the Network Manager estimate time slot capacity?
input: The Network Manager must consider the delays resulting from access rate, access mode, and relay delay in arriving at an End-to-End Response Time that is operationally acceptable. The Network Manager uses Terminal Response Time to estimate the time slot capacity (time slots per second) needed to meet End-to-End Response Time requirements.
output: The Network Manager uses Terminal Response Time to estimate the time slot capacity needed to meet End-to-End Response Time requirements.

instruction: What is the purpose of assigning JTIDS/MIDS network capacity?
input: 4.2.3.5 THROUGHPUT Assignment of the JTIDS/MIDS network capacity may be driven by throughput requirements.
output: The purpose is to meet throughput requirements.

instruction: What is throughput?
input: Throughput is a general term used to characterize the load ----- ###### performance of a system, given a set of inputs or stimuli. Throughput requirements are therefore dependent on the length of specific messages entering the system and the frequency with which these messages are exchanged.
output: Throughput is a general term used to characterize the load performance of a system, given a set of inputs or stimuli.

instruction: What is the frequency of periodic messages?
input: For periodic messages, such as surveillance track reports, the message frequency is the product of the total number of tracks to be exchanged per unit of time and the update rate of a track during the same unit of time. For nonperiodic messages, such as control commands or requests for support, the subscriber or his proponents must provide an estimate of frequency of given messages based upon scenarios or experience.
output: The frequency of periodic messages is the product of the total number of tracks to be exchanged per unit of time and the update rate of a track during the same unit of time.

instruction: What is the frequency of nonperiodic messages?
input: For periodic messages, such as surveillance track reports, the message frequency is the product of the total number of tracks to be exchanged per unit of time and the update rate of a track during the same unit of time. For nonperiodic messages, such as control commands or requests for support, the subscriber or his proponents must provide an estimate of frequency of given messages based upon scenarios or experience.
output: For nonperiodic messages, such as control commands or requests for support, the subscriber or his proponents must provide an estimate of frequency of given messages based upon scenarios or experience.

instruction: What is the formula for estimating throughput requirement?
input: The throughput requirement may then be estimated from the product of the average message length and the message frequency.
output: The throughput requirement may then be estimated from the product of the average message length and the message frequency.

instruction: What should be reduced to units of time slots per second?
input: The throughput requirement should also be reduced to units of time slots per second. The assignment of time slots then becomes dependent on whether throughput or response time requires more capacity.
output: Throughput requirement

instruction: What becomes dependent on whether throughput or response time requires more capacity?
input: The throughput requirement should also be reduced to units of time slots per second. The assignment of time slots then becomes dependent on whether throughput or response time requires more capacity.
output: The assignment of time slots

instruction: What are message update rates specified in?
input: Message update rates are specified in Table 4.1-3 and in the T/R rules for each message.
output: Table 4.1-3 and in the T/R rules for each message.

instruction: What is the purpose of rate matching in the context of interconnection with non-JTIDS/MIDS nets or interfacing certain types of platform systems?
input: 4.2.3.6 RATE MATCHING REQUIREMENTS When a PG is established for interconnection with nonJTIDS/MIDS nets or for interfacing certain types of platform systems, the requirement for rate matching may arise. Rate matching is required when the following two conditions exist simultaneously.
output: Rate matching is required when two conditions exist simultaneously: 1) A PG (Performance Group) is established for interconnection with non-JTIDS/MIDS networks, or for interfacing certain types of platform systems. 2) The rate matching requirement arises when these conditions are met.

instruction: What are the two main requirements for PG time slot assignment?
input: The first is that the size of the PG time slot assignment must match very closely an arbitrary value that cannot be matched by a single time slot block. The second is that the interval between the time slots must be nearly uniform. The need for a uniform interval arises when a PG containing multiple time slot blocks of different Recurrence Rate Numbers must be interfaced through a buffer with a channel having a uniform rate. The size of the buffer determines the maximum interval between the time slots in the PG.
output: The size of the PG time slot assignment must match very closely an arbitrary value that cannot be matched by a single time slot block, and the interval between the time slots must be nearly uniform.

instruction: How can a near match to both requirements be made?
input: By suitably assigning multiple time slot blocks of the same Recurrence Rate Number, a near match to both requirements can be made.
output: By suitably assigning multiple time slot blocks of the same Recurrence Rate Number.

instruction: What is the Recurrence Rate Number?
input: In general, the smaller the Recurrence Rate Number used, the closer the match will be (at the expense of increased fragmentation of the assignable capacity).
output: The text does not provide a specific definition of the Recurrence Rate Number, but it mentions that it is a factor used in determining the match between a resource and a request.

instruction: What does the text say about transmit access modes?
input: ----- ###### 4.2.3.7 TRANSMIT ACCESS MODES The transmit access modes identify the algorithms (rules and procedures) used by a JU in scheduling its transmissions. The scheduling of transmissions involves the assignment of the next available time slot, as constrained by the access mode, to the transmission of the message(s) waiting in queue.
output: The transmit access modes identify the algorithms used by a JU in scheduling its transmissions. This scheduling involves assigning the next available time slot, as constrained by the access mode, to the transmission of messages waiting in queue.

instruction: What are the four access modes defined?
input: Four access modes are defined: Dedicated Access mode, Contention Access mode, Time Slot Reallocation Access mode, and Call-Up Access mode.
output: The four access modes defined are Dedicated Access mode, Contention Access mode, Time Slot Reallocation Access mode, and Call-Up Access mode.

instruction: What is the purpose of using Dedicated Access mode in JTIDS/MIDS?
input: Network loading and the communications mode in use will have a bearing on which transmit access mode is selected. The transmit access modes are assigned as a part of the time slot block assignments for each PG. 4.2.3.7.1 DEDICATED ACCESS MODE Dedicated Access mode time slot assignments are used to increase the probability of receipt of a transmitted message. When there are sufficient time slots available in the network capacity to simultaneously satisfy the information exchange requirements of each JU, the Dedicated Access mode may be used. As the demand for time slots increases, a mixture of Dedicated Access mode and the other two modes will be required to provide each JU with sufficient transmission opportunities. Time slots used for the Dedicated Access mode are assigned to a terminal for its use in transmitting messages. Also, as in the case of the acknowledgement function, a Dedicated Access mode time slot can be assigned temporarily to another terminal for its use in transmitting a message. Normally one terminal participating in an organized JTIDS/MIDS net transmits a message in a time slot assigned as a dedicated access slot; however, Dedicated Access mode time slots may be reused by JUs either beyond or within LOS of each other, depending on the communications performance requirements of the involved JUs. 4.2.3.7.2 TIME SLOT REUSE IN THE DEDICATED ACCESS MODE In non-LOS situations, a Network Manager may assign the same dedicated access time slot blocks to JUs that do not directly communicate with one another or do not communicate with a common third JU using these assignments.
output: The Dedicated Access mode is used to increase the probability of receipt of a transmitted message. It assigns time slots to a terminal for its use in transmitting messages, and these slots can also be temporarily assigned to another terminal for message transmission.

instruction: What are the requirements for using Dedicated Access mode in JTIDS/MIDS?
input: Network loading and the communications mode in use will have a bearing on which transmit access mode is selected. The transmit access modes are assigned as a part of the time slot block assignments for each PG. 4.2.3.7.1 DEDICATED ACCESS MODE Dedicated Access mode time slot assignments are used to increase the probability of receipt of a transmitted message. When there are sufficient time slots available in the network capacity to simultaneously satisfy the information exchange requirements of each JU, the Dedicated Access mode may be used. As the demand for time slots increases, a mixture of Dedicated Access mode and the other two modes will be required to provide each JU with sufficient transmission opportunities. Time slots used for the Dedicated Access mode are assigned to a terminal for its use in transmitting messages. Also, as in the case of the acknowledgement function, a Dedicated Access mode time slot can be assigned temporarily to another terminal for its use in transmitting a message. Normally one terminal participating in an organized JTIDS/MIDS net transmits a message in a time slot assigned as a dedicated access slot; however, Dedicated Access mode time slots may be reused by JUs either beyond or within LOS of each other, depending on the communications performance requirements of the involved JUs. 4.2.3.7.2 TIME SLOT REUSE IN THE DEDICATED ACCESS MODE In non-LOS situations, a Network Manager may assign the same dedicated access time slot blocks to JUs that do not directly communicate with one another or do not communicate with a common third JU using these assignments.
output: To use Dedicated Access mode, there must be sufficient time slots available in the network capacity to simultaneously satisfy the information exchange requirements of each Joint User (JU). As the demand for time slots increases, a mixture of Dedicated Access mode and other modes will be required to provide each JU with sufficient transmission opportunities.

instruction: How are Dedicated Access mode time slots assigned in JTIDS/MIDS?
input: Network loading and the communications mode in use will have a bearing on which transmit access mode is selected. The transmit access modes are assigned as a part of the time slot block assignments for each PG. 4.2.3.7.1 DEDICATED ACCESS MODE Dedicated Access mode time slot assignments are used to increase the probability of receipt of a transmitted message. When there are sufficient time slots available in the network capacity to simultaneously satisfy the information exchange requirements of each JU, the Dedicated Access mode may be used. As the demand for time slots increases, a mixture of Dedicated Access mode and the other two modes will be required to provide each JU with sufficient transmission opportunities. Time slots used for the Dedicated Access mode are assigned to a terminal for its use in transmitting messages. Also, as in the case of the acknowledgement function, a Dedicated Access mode time slot can be assigned temporarily to another terminal for its use in transmitting a message. Normally one terminal participating in an organized JTIDS/MIDS net transmits a message in a time slot assigned as a dedicated access slot; however, Dedicated Access mode time slots may be reused by JUs either beyond or within LOS of each other, depending on the communications performance requirements of the involved JUs. 4.2.3.7.2 TIME SLOT REUSE IN THE DEDICATED ACCESS MODE In non-LOS situations, a Network Manager may assign the same dedicated access time slot blocks to JUs that do not directly communicate with one another or do not communicate with a common third JU using these assignments.
output: Dedicated Access mode time slots are assigned to a terminal for its use in transmitting messages. They can also be temporarily assigned to another terminal for message transmission. These slots can be reused by JUs either beyond or within Line-of-Sight (LOS) of each other, depending on the communications performance requirements of the involved JUs.

instruction: What is the role of Network Manager in JTIDS/MIDS?
input: Network loading and the communications mode in use will have a bearing on which transmit access mode is selected. The transmit access modes are assigned as a part of the time slot block assignments for each PG. 4.2.3.7.1 DEDICATED ACCESS MODE Dedicated Access mode time slot assignments are used to increase the probability of receipt of a transmitted message. When there are sufficient time slots available in the network capacity to simultaneously satisfy the information exchange requirements of each JU, the Dedicated Access mode may be used. As the demand for time slots increases, a mixture of Dedicated Access mode and the other two modes will be required to provide each JU with sufficient transmission opportunities. Time slots used for the Dedicated Access mode are assigned to a terminal for its use in transmitting messages. Also, as in the case of the acknowledgement function, a Dedicated Access mode time slot can be assigned temporarily to another terminal for its use in transmitting a message. Normally one terminal participating in an organized JTIDS/MIDS net transmits a message in a time slot assigned as a dedicated access slot; however, Dedicated Access mode time slots may be reused by JUs either beyond or within LOS of each other, depending on the communications performance requirements of the involved JUs. 4.2.3.7.2 TIME SLOT REUSE IN THE DEDICATED ACCESS MODE In non-LOS situations, a Network Manager may assign the same dedicated access time slot blocks to JUs that do not directly communicate with one another or do not communicate with a common third JU using these assignments.
output: The Network Manager assigns dedicated access time slot blocks to JUs that do not directly communicate with one another or do not communicate with a common third JU using these assignments, especially in non-LOS situations.

instruction: What should be determined to prevent transmission capture between JUs that are not interoperating?
input: Propagational attenuation should be determined to be sufficient to preclude possible transmission capture between JUs that are not interoperating.
output: Propagational attenuation should be determined to be sufficient.

instruction: What is the Contention Access mode used for when there are JUs demanding more time slots than available in the JTIDS/MIDS network capacity?
input: ----- ###### 4.2.3.7.3 CONTENTION ACCESS MODE When there are JUs demanding more time slots than are available in the JTIDS/MIDS network capacity, the Contention Access mode can be selected by the Network Manager.
output: The Contention Access mode can be selected by the Network Manager when there are JUs demanding more time slots than are available in the JTIDS/MIDS network capacity.

instruction: What is the purpose of time slots in the Contention Access mode?
input: Time slots assigned for the Contention Access mode form a pool that is shared by a community of terminals for transmitting and receiving messages.
output: Time slots are used to form a pool shared by a community of terminals for transmitting and receiving messages.

instruction: What is the purpose of this mode?
input: In this mode, more than one terminal can transmit messages in any specified time slot. If two or more transmissions occur in the same time slot, a receiving terminal will lock onto the message from the closest transmitting terminal, which may or may not be the message it needs.
output: To allow more than one terminal to transmit messages in any specified time slot.

instruction: How does a receiving terminal handle multiple transmissions in the same time slot?
input: In this mode, more than one terminal can transmit messages in any specified time slot. If two or more transmissions occur in the same time slot, a receiving terminal will lock onto the message from the closest transmitting terminal, which may or may not be the message it needs.
output: It locks onto the message from the closest transmitting terminal, which may or may not be the message it needs.

instruction: What is the earliest time of arrival (TOA) for the transmission?
input: The transmission with the earliest time of arrival (TOA) will be processed by the receiving terminal.
output: The text does not provide a specific time of arrival.

instruction: What is the usage of Contention Access mode?
input: The Contention Access mode can be used only in Communications Mode 1 (wideband transmissions).
output: It can be used only in Communications Mode 1 (wideband transmissions).

instruction: What mode is required for Contention Access?
input: The Contention Access mode can be used only in Communications Mode 1 (wideband transmissions).
output: Communications Mode 1 (wideband transmissions).

instruction: What is a time slot used for in the Contention Access mode?
input: Time slots are assignable to a particular pool for the Contention Access mode and are used by a terminal to transmit messages belonging to that pool.
output: Time slots are assignable to a particular pool for the Contention Access mode and are used by a terminal to transmit messages belonging to that pool.

instruction: What is the average rate of transmission time slots belonging to the pool?
input: Transmission time slots belonging to the pool are allowed at an average rate of one transmission per time interval.
output: One transmission per time interval.

instruction: What is the selection process for this transmission slot?
input: This transmission slot is selected from all assigned slots that occur during the time interval in a manner that is pseudorandom with respect to the selection process at all other terminals.
output: It is pseudorandom with respect to the selection process at all other terminals.

instruction: What is the purpose of the TIME SLOT REALLOCATION ACCESS MODE?
input: 4.2.3.7.4 TIME SLOT REALLOCATION ACCESS MODE This access mode can be selected by the Network Manager when the demand for time slots using dedicated assignments exceeds supply.
output: It can be selected by the Network Manager when the demand for time slots using dedicated assignments exceeds supply.

instruction: What is this mode useful for?
input: This mode is useful when user numbers and demands cannot be predicted at initialization and demands may fluctuate with changes in Reporting Responsibility, for example.
output: This mode is useful when user numbers and demands cannot be predicted at initialization and demands may fluctuate with changes in Reporting Responsibility, for example.

instruction: What is the purpose of this access mode?
input: This access mode allows the sharing of a specified pool of time slots, referred to as a reallocation pool, with other participating terminals to exchange messages other than voice.
output: To allow sharing of a reallocation pool with other participating terminals for exchanging messages other than voice.

instruction: What does a JU determine for each interval?
input: A JU determines its time slot requirements for each interval referred to as a reallocation period, and announces the percentage of the reallocation pool's time slots that it desires to use during the next reallocation period in a time slot reallocation message.
output: A JU determines its time slot requirements for each interval referred to as a reallocation period.

instruction: What is mutual dissemination?
input: A JU also repeats, in the same message, the requirements of any JUs previously received in a process known as mutual dissemination.
output: It is the process by which a JU repeats, in the same message, the requirements of any JUs previously received.

instruction: What does the text say about Time Slot Reallocation?
input: ----- ###### A JU that has implemented Time Slot Reallocation will be able to operate simultaneously in at least two reallocation pools. Each reallocation pool is associated with only one Network PG and time slots in that pool may be used only for messages from that Network PG. More than one reallocation pool may be operated in a single PG. However, in a single PG, no JU may transmit in more than one reallocation pool.
output: A JU that has implemented Time Slot Reallocation can operate simultaneously in at least two reallocation pools. Each reallocation pool is associated with only one Network PG and time slots in that pool may be used only for messages from that Network PG. More than one reallocation pool may be operated in a single PG. However, in a single PG, no JU may transmit in more than one reallocation pool.

instruction: What is the maximum number of time slot blocks that can be used for reallocation pool specification?
input: A reallocation pool must be specified in no more than 3 time slot blocks.

instruction: What do JUs allocate capacity for?
input: JUs allocate capacity to themselves according to their own demands and those heard from the other community members.
output: JUs allocate capacity for themselves according to their own demands and those heard from the other community members.

instruction: What does JUs do with their demands?
input: JUs scale their demands so that the total scaled demand is within the pool capacity.
output: JUs scale their demands so that the total scaled demand is within the pool capacity.

instruction: How do JUs select time slots?
input: JUs select time slots on a pseudo-random basis, avoiding time slots that they calculate have been allocated to JUs that have a higher priority in the selection sequence.
output: JUs select time slots on a pseudo-random basis, avoiding time slots that they calculate have been allocated to JUs that have a higher priority in the selection sequence.

instruction: What is the selection sequence based on?
input: The selection sequence is based on the number of JU demands received by a given JU, either directly, by relay, or by mutual dissemination.
output: The selection sequence is based on the number of JU demands received by a given JU, either directly, by relay, or by mutual dissemination.

instruction: What is the criteria for selecting time slots by the JU?
input: The JU hearing the lowest number of demand reports from other terminals selects time slots first and so on, ties being broken by Table Position Number and, if none, by Source Track Number.
output: The JU hearing the lowest number of demand reports from other terminals selects time slots first, with ties broken by Table Position Number and Source Track Number.

instruction: What is the role of the Network Manager in time slot selection?
input: Thus the Network Manager has no involvement in the time slot selection ordering, either dynamically or at initialization.
output: The Network Manager has no involvement in the time slot selection ordering, either dynamically or at initialization.

instruction: What is the combination of pseudo-random selection and ordering by receive count used for?
input: This combination of pseudo-random selection and ordering by receive count ensures that in very poor connectivity the access method degrades gracefully.
output: It ensures that in very poor connectivity the access method degrades gracefully.

instruction: What is the purpose of the Time Slot Reallocation Access mode?
input: In moderate connectivity a small amount of time slot reuse may occur. 4.2.3.7.5 TIME SLOT REUSE IN THE TIME SLOT REALLOCATION ACCESS MODE The Time Slot Reallocation Access mode is designed to prevent time slot reuse by uniformly scaling down JU capacity allocations in overload conditions.
output: To prevent time slot reuse by uniformly scaling down JU capacity allocations in overload conditions.

instruction: What is an example of a condition that may cause reuse?
input: Some reuse may occur in conditions of poor connectivity.
output: Poor connectivity

instruction: Can reuse occur under certain conditions?
input: Some reuse may occur in conditions of poor connectivity.
output: Yes, it can occur under conditions of poor connectivity.

instruction: What is the purpose of limiting the dissemination of demand information?
input: As an initialization option, Network Designers may limit the dissemination of the demand information deliberately so that reuse can occur among widely separated JUs.
output: To enable reuse among widely separated JUs.

instruction: What is the method to disseminate demand information?
input: This is done by setting the maximum dissemination hops parameter to the required number of repetitions of demand information.
output: Setting the maximum dissemination hops parameter to the required number of repetitions of demand information.

instruction: What is the initial entry requirement for JU participating in a PG using Time Slot Reallocation Access mode?
input: 4.2.3.7.6 TIME SLOT REALLOCATION INITIAL ENTRY Each JU that participates in a PG using the Time Slot Reallocation Access mode must initially transmit the J0.7 Time Slot Reallocation message in a Dedicated Access time slot or, if there is no Dedicated Access mode time slot ----- ###### assignment for the JU, in one of the initial entry time slots.
output: Each JU must initially transmit the J0.7 Time Slot Reallocation message in a Dedicated Access time slot or, if there is no Dedicated Access mode time slot, in one of the initial entry time slots.

instruction: What are initial entry time slot assignments?
input: Initial entry time slot assignments are basically dedicated access mode assignments with time slot reuse.
output: Initial entry time slot assignments are basically dedicated access mode assignments with time slot reuse.

instruction: What does a JU that has not joined the reallocation pool use to announce the percentage of the reallocation pool's time slots it desires to use during the next reallocation period?
input: A JU that has not joined the reallocation pool uses a time slot from one of these assignments to announce the percentage of the reallocation pool's time slots it desires to use during the next reallocation period.
output: A JU that has not joined the reallocation pool uses a time slot from one of these assignments to announce the percentage of the reallocation pool's time slots it desires to use during the next reallocation period.

instruction: What is the requirement for JUs that have a time slot assignment using Dedicated Access mode in the PG?
input: JUs that have a time slot assignment using Dedicated Access mode in the PG must use that assignment for this message transmission and do not need an initial entry time slot assignment.
output: They must use that assignment for this message transmission and do not need an initial entry time slot assignment.

instruction: What can a Network Manager limit time slot reuse of the Time Slot Reallocation Initial Entry time slot assignments by?
input: 4.2.3.7.7 TIME SLOT REUSE OF THE TIME SLOT REALLOCATION INITIAL ENTRY TIME SLOTS A Network Manager can limit time slot reuse of the Time Slot Reallocation Initial Entry time slot assignments by giving JUs Dedicated Access mode assignments. However, in situations of limited net capacity, initial entry time slots can be shared by all JUs in an assignment with this access mode. Since these initial entry time slots are used only to enter the reallocation pool, there is a small probability of use by more than one JU in a single time slot. The Network Manager assigns initial entry time slots to meet the response time requirement for JUs entering a reallocation pool.
output: By giving JUs Dedicated Access mode assignments.

instruction: What is the purpose of initial entry time slots?
input: 4.2.3.7.7 TIME SLOT REUSE OF THE TIME SLOT REALLOCATION INITIAL ENTRY TIME SLOTS A Network Manager can limit time slot reuse of the Time Slot Reallocation Initial Entry time slot assignments by giving JUs Dedicated Access mode assignments. However, in situations of limited net capacity, initial entry time slots can be shared by all JUs in an assignment with this access mode. Since these initial entry time slots are used only to enter the reallocation pool, there is a small probability of use by more than one JU in a single time slot. The Network Manager assigns initial entry time slots to meet the response time requirement for JUs entering a reallocation pool.
output: They are used only to enter the reallocation pool.

instruction: What is the probability of use by more than one JU in a single time slot for initial entry time slots?
input: 4.2.3.7.7 TIME SLOT REUSE OF THE TIME SLOT REALLOCATION INITIAL ENTRY TIME SLOTS A Network Manager can limit time slot reuse of the Time Slot Reallocation Initial Entry time slot assignments by giving JUs Dedicated Access mode assignments. However, in situations of limited net capacity, initial entry time slots can be shared by all JUs in an assignment with this access mode. Since these initial entry time slots are used only to enter the reallocation pool, there is a small probability of use by more than one JU in a single time slot. The Network Manager assigns initial entry time slots to meet the response time requirement for JUs entering a reallocation pool.
output: There is a small probability of use by more than one JU in a single time slot.

instruction: What is the purpose of CALL-UP ACCESS MODE?
input: 4.2.3.7.8 CALL-UP ACCESS MODE In the Call-Up Access mode, information exchange is controlled in the Roll Call or Round Robin modes.
output: Information exchange is controlled in the Roll Call or Round Robin modes.

instruction: What are the modes implemented by the terminals of the participating JUs?
input: When these modes are implemented by the terminals of the participating JUs, the PG time slot blocks are assigned in the Dedicated Access mode.
output: The modes implemented by the terminals of the participating JUs are not specified in the given text.

instruction: Who controls the Roll Call mode?
input: The Roll Call mode is controlled by a Network Manager who has been assigned this specific responsibility.
output: A Network Manager who has been assigned this specific responsibility.

instruction: What is the purpose of the J0.6 message?
input: The J0.6 message is used to initiate information exchange by a specific JU and is used by the JU to terminate the exchange.
output: To initiate and terminate information exchange by a specific JU.

instruction: What does the Round Robin mode require?
input: The Round Robin mode requires the assignment of a sequential position to each JU for information exchange.
output: The Round Robin mode requires the assignment of a sequential position to each JU for information exchange.

instruction: What is controlled by the J0.6 message?
input: It is also controlled by the J0.6 message.
output: The text does not specify what is controlled by the J0.6 message.

instruction: What characteristic do both Call-Up Access modes have?
input: Both of the Call-Up Access modes have the characteristic that, within a fixed assignment of time slot blocks, the response time automatically increases with increasing traffic loads and decreases with decreasing traffic loads.
output: Both have the characteristic that, within a fixed assignment of time slot blocks, the response time automatically increases with increasing traffic loads and decreases with decreasing traffic loads.

instruction: How can platform systems control the response time?
input: The platform systems can control the response time by controlling the amount of information that is exchanged.
output: By controlling the amount of information that is exchanged.

instruction: What is the role of the platform system in controlling the characteristics of information exchange?
input: Because of the role of the platform system ----- ###### in controlling the characteristics of the information exchange, the Call-Up Access modes should be used only when all participating JUs in the PGC have the requisite capability. The capacity that must to be allocated to a PG that uses the Call-Up Access mode is determined in the same way as for any other PG using a Dedicated Access mode.
output: The platform system controls the characteristics of information exchange by using Call-Up Access modes.

instruction: What is the purpose of terminals receiving messages?
input: 4.2.3.7.9 RECEIVE ASSIGNMENTS Terminals shall receive messages as follows: a.
output: Terminals shall receive messages as part of their functionality.

instruction: What is the context of the text?
input: In all time slots that are assigned specifically as receive slots, on the nets specified in the assignments.
output: The text is discussing time slots assigned for receiving on specified nets.

instruction: What is the task?
input: b.
output: To summarize and extract multiple questions and answer pairs from the given text and return them in list format.

instruction: What does the text say about assigning transmit and paired relay transmit time slots?
input: In all assigned transmit and paired relay transmit time slots that are not used by the terminal for its own transmissions, on the nets specified for the transmit time slots. c. In all time slots that have not been assigned specifically as either receive or transmit time slots, on the Initial Entry Network PG net.
output: The text states that in all assigned transmit and paired relay transmit time slots that are not used by the terminal for its own transmissions, on the nets specified for the transmit time slots. Additionally, in all time slots that have not been assigned specifically as either receive or transmit time slots, on the Initial Entry Network PG net.

instruction: What does the text refer to when it mentions "those time slots that are specified for message acknowledgements"?
input: d. During those time slots that are specified for message acknowledgements, even when such messages requiring acknowledgement are not addressed to the terminal.
output: The text refers to time slots that are allocated for the acknowledgment of messages, even when those messages requiring acknowledgment are not addressed to the terminal.

instruction: What is the rule regarding the use of a Network PG in message reception?
input: The Network PG to which a time slot is assigned shall not be used as a criterion for rejecting a received message.
output: A Network PG to which a time slot is assigned shall not be used as a criterion for rejecting a received message.

instruction: What is the capacity limit for a single net in JTIDS/MIDS?
input: 4.2.3.8 PARTICIPATION GROUPS ON MULTINETS JTIDS/MIDS capacity on a single net is limited to 128 time slots per second.
output: The capacity on a single net is limited to 128 time slots per second.

instruction: What is the maximum capacity of a PG?
input: Therefore, no PG may be larger than 128 time slots per second. When the throughput or response time requirements exceed the available capacity of a single net, a PG may be assigned blocks of time slots on other nets. The Network Manager must arrange the blocks from other nets so that minimum conflict (overlap) results if users require interoperability on several PGs. A multinetted PG may have some time slot blocks on one net and other time ----- ###### slot blocks on another net, provided that no time slot within a PG occurs simultaneously with another time slot in the same PG.
output: A PG may not be larger than 128 time slots per second.

instruction: How do multiple PGs handle interoperability?
input: Therefore, no PG may be larger than 128 time slots per second. When the throughput or response time requirements exceed the available capacity of a single net, a PG may be assigned blocks of time slots on other nets. The Network Manager must arrange the blocks from other nets so that minimum conflict (overlap) results if users require interoperability on several PGs. A multinetted PG may have some time slot blocks on one net and other time ----- ###### slot blocks on another net, provided that no time slot within a PG occurs simultaneously with another time slot in the same PG.
output: If users require interoperability on several PGs, the Network Manager must arrange blocks of time slots on other nets to minimize conflict (overlap).

instruction: What is the rule for assigning time slot blocks on different nets?
input: Therefore, no PG may be larger than 128 time slots per second. When the throughput or response time requirements exceed the available capacity of a single net, a PG may be assigned blocks of time slots on other nets. The Network Manager must arrange the blocks from other nets so that minimum conflict (overlap) results if users require interoperability on several PGs. A multinetted PG may have some time slot blocks on one net and other time ----- ###### slot blocks on another net, provided that no time slot within a PG occurs simultaneously with another time slot in the same PG.
output: A multinetted PG can have time slot blocks on one net and other time slot blocks on another net, provided that no time slot within a PG occurs simultaneously with another time slot in the same PG.

instruction: What message is used to associate blocks of time slots and their associated cryptovariables with a specific PG number?
input: 4.2.3.9 MESSAGES USED IN ASSIGNING PARTICIPATION GROUPS The J0.3 Time Slot Assignment message is used to associate blocks of time slots and their associated cryptovariables with a specific PG number. The J0.7 message is used to request time slots within PGs that contain time slot reallocation pools.
output: The J0.3 Time Slot Assignment message is used to associate blocks of time slots and their associated cryptovariables with a specific PG number.

instruction: What are Network PGs used for?
input: 4.2.3.10 NETWORK PARTICIPATION GROUPS DESCRIPTION Network PGs have been defined to support Link 16 information exchange as follows: PG 1 -Initial Entry PG 2 -RTT-A PG 3 -RTT-B PG 4 -Network Management PG 5 -PPLI and Status Group A PG 6 -PPLI and Status Group B PG 7 -Surveillance PG 8 -Mission Management/Weapons Coordination and Management PG 9 -Control PG 10 -Electronic Warfare PG 12 -Voice Group A PG 13 -Voice Group B PG 19 -NonC[2] JU-to-NonC[2] JU A PG 20 -NonC[2] JU-to-NonC[2] JU B PG 21 -Engagement Coordination PG 22 -Composite A PG 23 -Composite B PG 27 -Joint Net PPLI PG 28 -Distributed Network Management PG 29 -Residual Messages PG 30 -IJMS Position and Status PG 31 -Other IJMS Messages ----- ###### (Network PG numbers not listed above are currently undefined but may be specified for use in tactical communications plan(s) in accordance with interface operating procedures.) Participation in a Network PG is the organization and execution of the transmission of messages according to message label and sublabel as described in the JTIDS/MIDS Class 2 System Segment Specification.
output: Network PGs are used to support Link 16 information exchange by organizing and executing the transmission of messages according to message label and sublabel as described in the JTIDS/MIDS Class 2 System Segment Specification.

instruction: What does the host TDS specify for message transmission?
input: The host TDS will normally specify in which Network PG a message is to be transmitted. However, for the guidance of network designers and the Network Manager, a standard Network PG and other applicable Network PGs are identified for each message in Table 4.2-1.
output: The host TDS specifies in which Network PG a message is to be transmitted.

instruction: What does the text say about JUs and message exchange?

output: The messages applicable for these are 5, 27, 4, 7.

instruction: What is the Initial Entry Network PG?
input: The time slots that satisfy this criterion define the Initial Entry Network PG, which is a fixed assignment shared by all terminals.
output: The time slots that satisfy a certain criterion, which is a fixed assignment shared by all terminals.

instruction: What does the text describe?
input: The fixed block assignments are time slots (512 x N) of Set A, where N is equal to integers 0 through 63. This corresponds to the assignment of Time Slot 0, Set A, with the Recurrence Rate Number equal to 6, and a Net Number equal to 0.
output: The text describes fixed block assignments as time slots of Set A, where N ranges from 0 to 63.

instruction: What is the purpose of the Network PG in the context of RTT?
input: 4.2.3.10.2 ROUND-TRIP-TIMING NETWORK PARTICIPATION GROUP A terminal can accept and use one or more blocks of time slots for transmitting RTT Interrogations and Replies. This Network PG may be used for either RTT-A Interrogations in a Dedicated Access mode or RTT-B Interrogations in a Contention Access mode, or time slots may be assigned within the Network PG for each type.
output: The Network PG is used for either RTT-A Interrogations in a Dedicated Access mode or RTT-B Interrogations in a Contention Access mode, or time slots may be assigned within the Network PG for each type.

instruction: What is the rate at which RTT Interrogations are transmitted?
input: The rate at which RTT Interrogations are transmitted conforms to the requirements for achieving and maintaining Fine Synchronization.
output: The rate at which RTT Interrogations are transmitted conforms to the requirements for achieving and maintaining Fine Synchronization.

instruction: What document describes the requirements?
input: These requirements are described in the JTIDS/MIDS Technical Description, Section 3.0 Terms and Definitions.
output: The JTIDS/MIDS Technical Description, Section 3.0 Terms and Definitions.

instruction: What does the text say about Network Participation Group?
input: 4.2.3.10.3 NETWORK MANAGEMENT NETWORK PARTICIPATION GROUP A terminal can accept and use one or more blocks of time slots for transmitting J0 messages. This Network PG may be used for all J0 messages, except for the J0.0 and J0.2 Network Time Update message, in any access mode assigned. J2 messages may be transmitted in a Dedicated Access mode in time slots of this Network PG when there are no J0 messages to be transmitted. 4.2.3.10.4 PRECISE PARTICIPANT LOCATION AND IDENTIFICATION AND STATUS NETWORK PARTICIPATION GROUP A terminal can accept and use one or more blocks of time slots for transmitting J2 messages in the access mode specified for the transmission.
output: The text describes Network Participation Group as a mechanism where a terminal can accept and use one or more blocks of time slots for transmitting J0 messages. This group is used for all J0 messages, except for the J0.0 and J0.2 Network Time Update message, in any access mode assigned. Additionally, J2 messages may be transmitted in a Dedicated Access mode in time slots of this Network PG when there are no J0 messages to be transmitted.

instruction: What are the three specified groups a terminal can operate with?
input: A terminal can operate with three specified groups referred to as the Special Group (Group A), the Common Group (Group B), and the Joint Net.
output: The three specified groups are the Special Group (Group A), the Common Group (Group B), and the Joint Net.

instruction: What does the terminal always transmit in Group B and the Joint Net?
input: The terminal always transmits its J2 messages in Group B and the Joint Net (except when transmitting Conditional Radio Silence as specified below) at ----- ###### the specified access rate and mode. The terminal also transmits its J2 messages in Group A, at the specified rate, as follows: (1) when so commanded through the subscriber interface, (2) when it is an active, unconditional relay or an active conditional relay for the main net, voice channel, or control channel relay function, (3) just before it goes to the Conditional Radio Silence mode, or (4) when the host aircraft has set the Flight Leader Indicator in its PPLI message.
output: The terminal always transmits its J2 messages in Group B and the Joint Net at the specified access rate and mode, except when transmitting Conditional Radio Silence as specified below.

instruction: Under what conditions does the terminal transmit its J2 messages in Group A?
input: The terminal always transmits its J2 messages in Group B and the Joint Net (except when transmitting Conditional Radio Silence as specified below) at ----- ###### the specified access rate and mode. The terminal also transmits its J2 messages in Group A, at the specified rate, as follows: (1) when so commanded through the subscriber interface, (2) when it is an active, unconditional relay or an active conditional relay for the main net, voice channel, or control channel relay function, (3) just before it goes to the Conditional Radio Silence mode, or (4) when the host aircraft has set the Flight Leader Indicator in its PPLI message.
output: The terminal transmits its J2 messages in Group A under the following conditions: (1) when so commanded through the subscriber interface, (2) when it is an active, unconditional relay or an active conditional relay for the main net, voice channel, or control channel relay function, (3) just before it goes to the Conditional Radio Silence mode, or (4) when the host aircraft has set the Flight Leader Indicator in its PPLI message.

instruction: What does the terminal set as directed by the subscriber interface?
input: The terminal shall set the Flight Leader Indicator as directed by the subscriber interface.
output: The Flight Leader Indicator.

instruction: What is the rule for Conditional Radio Silence transmission?
input: The terminal shall only transmit Conditional Radio Silence in one NPG.
output: The terminal shall only transmit Conditional Radio Silence in one NPG.

instruction: What happens if a transmit slot is not available in Group A?
input: If a transmit slot is not available in Group A, it will then go to Group B. If a transmit slot is not available in Group B, it will then go to the Joint Net.
output: It will then go to Group B.

instruction: What happens if a transmit slot is not available in Group B?
input: If a transmit slot is not available in Group A, it will then go to Group B. If a transmit slot is not available in Group B, it will then go to the Joint Net.
output: It will then go to the Joint Net.

instruction: What are the J13 Platform and System Status messages?
input: The J13 Platform and System Status messages may be transmitted in the same time slot as J2 messages. Only J2 and J13 messages shall be transmitted in these slots at the specified rate except when in Test Mode 1. When in Test Mode 1, the terminal shall transmit a J0.1 Test message in place of the J2 message in all slots in which it would normally transmit a J2 message.
output: The J13 Platform and System Status messages may be transmitted in the same time slot as J2 messages.

instruction: What is Test Mode 1?
input: The J13 Platform and System Status messages may be transmitted in the same time slot as J2 messages. Only J2 and J13 messages shall be transmitted in these slots at the specified rate except when in Test Mode 1. When in Test Mode 1, the terminal shall transmit a J0.1 Test message in place of the J2 message in all slots in which it would normally transmit a J2 message.
output: In Test Mode 1, the terminal shall transmit a J0.1 Test message in place of the J2 message in all slots in which it would normally transmit a J2 message.

instruction: What is the purpose of the surveillance network participation group?
input: 4.2.3.10.5 SURVEILLANCE NETWORK PARTICIPATION GROUP A terminal can accept and use one or more blocks of time slots for transmitting surveillance data in the access mode specified for the transmission. Each group of C[2] JUs that are to participate in a single Surveillance Network PG are to be assigned time slot blocks on a net that supports the Surveillance Network PG.
output: The purpose of the surveillance network participation group is to allow terminals to accept and use time slot blocks for transmitting surveillance data in the access mode specified for transmission.

instruction: What does the text say about the Mission Management and Weapons Coordination and Management messages?
input: 4.2.3.10.6 MISSION MANAGEMENT/WEAPONS COORDINATION AND MANAGEMENT NETWORK PARTICIPATION GROUP A terminal can accept and use one or more blocks of time slots for transmitting the Mission Management and the Weapons Coordination and Management messages in the access mode specified for the transmission.
output: The text states that a terminal can accept and use one or more blocks of time slots for transmitting the Mission Management and Weapons Coordination and Management messages. The transmission is done in the access mode specified for the transmission.

instruction: What is the purpose of the Paired Slot Relay mode in this Network PG?
input: Some or all of the time slots in this Network PG can be assigned in the Paired Slot Relay mode, and the J0.5 Repromulgation Relay message can be used with the messages in this Network PG.
output: The Paired Slot Relay mode allows some or all of the time slots in this Network PG to be assigned.

instruction: What is the purpose of Control Network Participation Groups?
input: ----- ###### 4.2.3.10.7 CONTROL NETWORK PARTICIPATION GROUPS A terminal can accept and use one or more blocks of time slots for transmission of Control information.
output: A terminal can accept and use one or more blocks of time slots for transmission of Control information.

instruction: What does the text say about net numbers and channels?
input: When the net number is not specified, the block assignment establishes a set of subscriber-selectable channels (stacked net). The terminal enables the subscriber to select a net number from 0 through 126 as a channel. Selection of net number 127 by the subscriber indicates that no channel is in effect for that terminal in that control group.
output: When the net number is not specified, the block assignment establishes a set of subscriber-selectable channels (stacked net). The terminal enables the subscriber to select a net number from 0 through 126 as a channel. Selection of net number 127 by the subscriber indicates that no channel is in effect for that terminal in that control group.

instruction: What is the main idea of the text?
input: It is possible to assign separate cryptovariables to subsets of these stacked nets.
output: The text discusses assigning separate cryptovariables to subsets of stacked nets.

instruction: What is a Control Network PG?
input: A specific Control Network PG is assigned to limited sets of JUs for specific tactical operations.
output: A specific Control Network PG is assigned to limited sets of JUs for specific tactical operations.

instruction: What are the different time slot assignment modes?
input: The time slot assignments for each PG may be subdivided into subsets of slots assigned to each participant in the Dedicated Access mode, assigned in the Contention Access mode, or assigned in the Time Slot Reallocation Access mode.
output: The different time slot assignment modes are Dedicated Access, Contention Access, and Time Slot Reallocation Access.

instruction: What is the terminal's capability regarding time slots?
input: The terminal is also capable of accepting blocks of time slots for control with a net number assigned. In this case, the terminal shall use these time slots on the specified net, instead of the applicable common group of time slots, when that net number is selected as a channel using the selector for the applicable common group.
output: The terminal can accept blocks of time slots for control with a net number assigned. When a net number is selected as a channel using the selector for the applicable common group, the terminal will use these time slots on the specified net instead of the applicable common group of time slots.

instruction: What does a terminal accept and use for voice transmission?
input: 4.2.3.10.8 VOICE A terminal can accept and use one or more blocks of time slots for voice transmission. The terminal is capable of accepting two common groups of time slots for voice.
output: A terminal can accept and use one or more blocks of time slots for voice transmission.

instruction: How many common groups of time slots for voice can a terminal accept?
input: 4.2.3.10.8 VOICE A terminal can accept and use one or more blocks of time slots for voice transmission. The terminal is capable of accepting two common groups of time slots for voice.
output: A terminal is capable of accepting two common groups of time slots for voice.

instruction: What are the designated Voice Groups?
input: They are designated Voice Group A and Voice Group B.
output: Voice Group A and Voice Group B.

instruction: What is the net number assigned?
input: The net number is not assigned.
output: Not assigned.

instruction: What does a net number 127 indicate in this context?
input: In this case, for each voice group, the terminal enables the subscriber to select a net number (0 through 126) as the channel. Selection of net number 127 by the subscriber indicates that no channel is in effect for that terminal in that voice group.
output: It indicates that no channel is in effect for that terminal in that voice group.

instruction: What can multiple subscribers do with the same voice channel?
input: Multiple subscribers may select the same voice channel, as determined by the communication requirements.
output: Multiple subscribers may select the same voice channel, as determined by the communication requirements.

instruction: What is the possibility of assigning separate cryptovariables to subsets of these stacked nets?
input: It is possible to assign separate cryptovariables to subsets of these stacked nets.
output: Yes, it is possible to assign separate cryptovariables to subsets of these stacked nets.

instruction: What does the terminal use instead of the applicable common group of time slots when a specific net number is selected?
input: The terminal is also capable of accepting blocks of time slots for voice where the net number is assigned. In this case, the terminal shall use these ----- ###### time slots on the specified net, instead of the applicable common group of time slots, when that net number is selected as a channel using the selector for the applicable common group.
output: The terminal uses the assigned blocks of time slots for voice on the specified net number.

instruction: What can the terminal utilize each of the time slot blocks to transmit?
input: The terminal can utilize each of the time slot blocks to transmit digitized voice data.
output: Digitized voice data.

instruction: What are the two types of voice transmission?
input: Voice can be transmitted using either nonerror-coded free text messages or error-coded free text messages as specified during initialization, depending on the voice data rate.
output: Nonerror-coded free text messages and error-coded free text messages.

instruction: What factors determine the specific message type used by the terminal?
input: The terminal determines the specific message type to be used depending on the voice group block assignment slot type, the Recurrence Rate, and the error coding option.
output: The specific message type used by the terminal is determined by the voice group block assignment slot type, the Recurrence Rate, and the error coding option.

instruction: What is the normal handling of voice messages?
input: Voice messages shall normally be handled as nonerror-coded free text messages.
output: Voice messages shall normally be handled as nonerror-coded free text messages.

instruction: What is the purpose of the Participation Group for Distributed Network Management in the U.S. Army terminal?
input: 4.2.3.10.9 PARTICIPATION GROUPS FOR DISTRIBUTED NETWORK MANAGEMENT The U.S. Army terminal can accept and use time slot assignments in this Participation Group to conduct intra-Army communications.
output: The U.S. Army terminal can accept and use time slot assignments in this Participation Group to conduct intra-Army communications.

instruction: What is the purpose of transmitting net management messages in the broadcast mode in this Participation Group?
input: Net management messages to establish, maintain, and report connectivity among community members will be transmitted in the broadcast mode in this Participation Group.
output: To establish, maintain, and report connectivity among community members.

instruction: What is the purpose of the PARTICIPATION GROUP FOR RESIDUAL MESSAGES?
input: 4.2.3.10.10 PARTICIPATION GROUP FOR RESIDUAL MESSAGES A terminal can accept and use time slots in this Participation Group for transmission of messages for which no specific Participation Group has been defined. 4.2.3.10.11 PARTICIPATION GROUPS FOR AN IJMS INTERFACE Terminals with a bilingual capability can accept and use time slots in these two Participation Groups.
output: The PARTICIPATION GROUP FOR RESIDUAL MESSAGES allows a terminal to accept and use time slots for transmission of messages for which no specific PARTICIPATION GROUP has been defined.

instruction: What are the two PARTICIPATION GROUPS FOR AN IJMS INTERFACE?
input: 4.2.3.10.10 PARTICIPATION GROUP FOR RESIDUAL MESSAGES A terminal can accept and use time slots in this Participation Group for transmission of messages for which no specific Participation Group has been defined. 4.2.3.10.11 PARTICIPATION GROUPS FOR AN IJMS INTERFACE Terminals with a bilingual capability can accept and use time slots in these two Participation Groups.
output: The two PARTICIPATION GROUPS FOR AN IJMS INTERFACE are not explicitly stated in the given text, but it is mentioned that terminals with bilingual capability can accept and use time slots in these groups.

instruction: What are JUs participating in an interface with terminals that implement the Interim JTIDS/MIDS Message Specification (IJMS) used for?
input: These are used by JUs participating in an interface with terminals that implement the Interim JTIDS/MIDS Message Specification (IJMS).
output: These are used by JUs participating in an interface with terminals that implement the Interim JTIDS/MIDS Message Specification (IJMS).

instruction: What is the purpose of JUs participating in an interface with terminals that implement the Interim JTIDS/MIDS Message Specification (IJMS)?
input: These are used by JUs participating in an interface with terminals that implement the Interim JTIDS/MIDS Message Specification (IJMS).
output: These are used by JUs participating in an interface with terminals that implement the Interim JTIDS/MIDS Message Specification (IJMS).

instruction: What message specification is implemented by terminals that communicate with JUs?
input: These are used by JUs participating in an interface with terminals that implement the Interim JTIDS/MIDS Message Specification (IJMS).
output: The Interim JTIDS/MIDS Message Specification (IJMS) is implemented by terminals that communicate with JUs.

instruction: What is the purpose of additional Net Management related Needline PGs?
input: ----- ###### 4.2.3.10.12 PARTICIPATION GROUPS FOR JTIDS UNITS PARTICIPATING IN NET CONTROL STATION COMMUNITIES JUs participating in a given NCS community must be capable of participating in additional Net Management related Needline PGs. These Needline PGs are required to provide capacity for solicitation of new entrants into the community, initialization of Net Control, and connectivity information. These Net Management related Needline PGs are described in the following subparagraphs.
output: The purpose of additional Net Management related Needline PGs is to provide capacity for solicitation of new entrants into the community, initialization of Net Control, and connectivity information.

instruction: What is the content of the text?
input: a.
output: The text is empty.

instruction: What is Net Status Needline Participation Group?
input: Net Status Needline Participation Group.
output: The text does not provide specific information about the Net Status Needline Participation Group.

instruction: What does the text say about the transmission and reception of J1.4 Communicant Status messages in a terminal?
input: A terminal can accept and use one block of time slots for transmitting and receiving J1.4 Communicant Status messages. The terminal transmits its J1.4 message in dedicated time slots, according to the Net Number, Control Net Entry and Time Slot Offset, Control Net Entry assigned to it by the J1.5 Net Control Initialization message. The terminal receives the J1.4 message of other JUs participating in NCS communities in all other time slots given by the Overall Recurrence Rate, Net Status Participation Group value which is also provided in the J1.5 message. By assigning a different Time Slot Number, Net Status Participation Group value and Time Slot Set, Net Status Participation Group value to each JU in the NCS community, the NCS insures that each participating JU has the opportunity to transmit its J1.4 message without interfering with other participating JUs, exactly once every cycle determined by the Recurrence Rate, Net Status Participation Group value.
output: A terminal transmits its J1.4 message in dedicated time slots, according to the Net Number, Control Net Entry, and Time Slot Offset assigned by the J1.5 Net Control Initialization message. It receives the J1.4 messages of other JUs participating in NCS communities in all other time slots determined by the Overall Recurrence Rate and Net Status Participation Group values provided in the J1.5 message.

instruction: What will be reported periodically in the Net Status Needline Participation Group?
input: The J1.4 messages will be reported periodically in the Net Status Needline Participation Group. The following messages will also be allowed in this Needline Participation Group (pre-empting the J1.4 messages): (1) The J2.5 Land (Ground) Point PPLI message, reported periodically using the ratio of one PPLI message to every 10(5-20, 1) J1.4 messages.
output: The J1.4 messages will be reported periodically in the Net Status Needline Participation Group.

instruction: What other messages are allowed in this Needline Participation Group?
input: The J1.4 messages will be reported periodically in the Net Status Needline Participation Group. The following messages will also be allowed in this Needline Participation Group (pre-empting the J1.4 messages): (1) The J2.5 Land (Ground) Point PPLI message, reported periodically using the ratio of one PPLI message to every 10(5-20, 1) J1.4 messages.
output: The J2.5 Land (Ground) Point PPLI message, reported periodically using the ratio of one PPLI message to every 10(5-20, 1) J1.4 messages.

instruction: What is the purpose of a J1.1 Connectivity Status message?
input: (2) A J1.1 Connectivity Status message, relayed from a JU wishing to enter the NCS community. (3) A J0.6 message, initiated when a JU determines a Needline PG inadequacy or failure that must be reported to the NCS.
output: To relay information about a JU's connectivity status to the NCS community.

instruction: What is the purpose of a J0.6 message?
input: (2) A J1.1 Connectivity Status message, relayed from a JU wishing to enter the NCS community. (3) A J0.6 message, initiated when a JU determines a Needline PG inadequacy or failure that must be reported to the NCS.
output: To report a Needline PG inadequacy or failure to the NCS.

instruction: What is the purpose of relaying Net Status Needline Participation Group messages to the Net Control Station?
input: ----- ###### b. Relaying of Net Status Needline Participation Group Messages to the Net Control Station.
output: The purpose is to ensure effective communication and coordination among participants within the Net Control Station.

instruction: What must be received by the NCS in NCS communities?
